{{Infobox planet |minorplanet = yes |background = #FFC2E0 |name = {{mp|2013 ET}} |symbol = |image = Asteroid20130318-full.jpg |image_size = 270 |caption = Radar imaging of {{mp|2013 ET}} |discovery_ref = {{cite web|title=2013 ET|url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?utf8=✓&object_id=2013+ET|publisher=[[Minor Planet Center]]|accessdate=21 August 2017}} |discoverer = [[Catalina Sky Survey]] |discovered = March 3, 2013 |discovery_site = [[Mount Lemmon Observatory|Mount Lemmon Obs.]]
{{small|(first observed only)}} |mpc_name = 2013 ET |mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]] |alt_names = MPO 307059 |orbit_ref = {{cite sbdb|title=(2013 ET)|id=3629117|accessdate=21 August 2017}} |epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) |uncertainty = 3 |observation_arc = 6 [[Day|d]] |aphelion = {{Convert|1.66881|AU|Gm|abbr=on|lk=on}} |perihelion = {{Convert|0.74239|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} |semimajor = {{Convert|1.20560|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} |eccentricity = 0.38421 |period = 1.32 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (483.506 [[Julian year (astronomy)|d]])
1.32 [[Year|yr]] |avg_speed = |inclination = 4.85153° |asc_node = 171.316° |mean_anomaly = 97.151[[Degree (angle)|°]] |mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.74418|sup=ms}} /day |arg_peri = 81.911° |satellites = |moid = {{Convert|0.00375179|AU|km|abbr=on}} |mercury_moid = {{Convert|0.28725|AU|km|abbr=on}} |dimensions = {{cvt|100|m|ft|lk=on}} |sidereal_day = |albedo = |spectral_type = |abs_magnitude = 23.1 }} '''2013 ET''' is a [[near-Earth asteroid]] that was first observed on March 3, 2013, six days before its closest approach to [[Earth]]. It is estimated to be around {{convert|100|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} wide.{{cite web|last=Wall |first=Mike |url=http://www.space.com/20085-asteroid-buzzes-earth-this-weekend.html |title=Big Asteroid to Zoom By Earth This Weekend |work=Space.com |date=March 5, 2013}} Its closest approach to Earth was {{convert|0.0065207|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on|}} on March 9, 2013 at 12:09 UT.{{cite web|last=Gray |first=Melissa |url=http://lightyears.blogs.cnn.com/2013/03/07/asteroid-to-fly-past-earth-this-weekend/?hpt=hp_t3 |title=Asteroid to fly past Earth this weekend |work=Light Years |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=March 7, 2013}} The asteroid also makes close approaches to [[Mars]] and [[Venus]]. The asteroid was imaged by [[Goldstone Deep Space Communications Complex|Goldstone]] [[radar astronomy|radar]] on March 10, 2013. 2013 ET was one of four asteroids that passed in the vicinity of Earth during one week in early March 2013.{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/20149-asteroids-buzz-earth-week.html|title=Four Asteroids Buzz Earth in Single Week|work=Space.com|access-date=2018-11-13}} The other asteroids in this group besides 2013 ET, included [[2013 EC]], [[2013 EC20]], and [[2013 EN20]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/20149-asteroids-buzz-earth-week.html|title=Four Asteroids Buzz Earth in Single Week|work=Space.com|access-date=2018-11-13}} == See also == *[[List of asteroid close approaches to Earth in 2013]] * [[2013 EC]] * [[2013 PJ10]] * [[List of asteroid close approaches to Earth]] * [[List of Near-Earth asteroids by distance from Sun]] * [[Near-Earth Asteroid Tracking]] == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |date=2012-03-04 |title=MPEC 2013-E14 : 2013 ET |publisher=IAU [[Minor Planet Center]] |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K13/K13E14.html |accessdate=2012-03-09}} (K13E00T) {{cite web |date=2013-03-07 |title=2013 ET Goldstone Radar Observations Planning |publisher=NASA/JPL Asteroid Radar Research |author=Dr. Lance A. M. Benner |url=http://echo.jpl.nasa.gov/asteroids/2013ET/2013ET_planning.html |accessdate=2013-03-09}} {{cite web |date=2013-03-18 |title=Goldstone Radar Snags Images of Asteroid 2013 ET |publisher=NASA/JPL |author=DC Agle |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?release=2013-101 |accessdate=2013-03-19}} }} == External links == * {{JPL small body}} {{use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{2013 in space}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2013 ET}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Radar-imaged asteroids|#]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2013|20130309]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2013|20130303]] {{NE-asteroid-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Components of anxiety buffers */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Journal of personality and social psychology → Journal of Personality and Social Psychology using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{orphan|date=May 2014}}
'''Anxiety buffer disruption theory''' (ABDT) is an application of [[terror management theory]] to explain an individual's reaction to a traumatic event, which leads to [[post traumatic stress disorder]].<ref name="mainpaper">Pyszczynski, T., & Kesebir, P. (2011). Anxiety buffer disruption theory: A terror management account of posttraumatic stress disorder. Anxiety, Stress, & Coping, 24(1), 3–26.</ref> Terror management theory posits that humans, unlike any other organism, are uniquely aware that death is the inevitable outcome of life. When thoughts of death are made salient, such as when a terrorist attack carries those thoughts into the level of consciousness, humans are subject to debilitating anxiety unless it can be "buffered." Humans respond to the anxiety and dread [[mortality salience]] produces by clinging to their [[World view|cultural worldview]], through [[self-esteem]] and also [[Interpersonal relationship|close personal relationships]].<ref name="Miller">Miller, C. & Landau, M. (2005) Communication and terrorism: a terror management theory perspective. Communication Research Reports. Vol. 22 Nos 1–4 pages 79–88.</ref> Cultural worldviews, with their cultural norms, religious beliefs and moral values infuse life with meaning. They give life a feeling of normalcy and also a feeling of control. There is no way to definitely prove one's cultural world view, there they are fragile human constructs and must be maintained. Clinging to a cultural worldview and self-esteem buffer the anxiety connected to thoughts of mortality.<ref name="luo">Luo, S., Shi, Z., Yang, X., Wang., X. & Han, S. (2014) Reminders of mortality decrease midcingulate activity in response to others' suffering. SCAN (9) 477–486.</ref> When thoughts of death are salient, humans are drawn to their cultural world view which "stipulates appropriate social requirements, and standards for valued conduct, while instilling one's life with meaning, order and permanence." <ref name="mainpaper"/>
When a traumatic experience cannot be assimilated into a currently held cultural worldview, the anxiety-buffering mechanisms are disrupted.<ref name="edmonson">Edmondson, D., Chaudoir, S. R., Mills, M. A., Park, C. L., Holub, J., & Bartkowiak, J. M. (2011). From shattered assumptions to weakened worldviews: Trauma symptoms signal anxiety buffer disruption. Journal of Loss and Trauma, 16(4), 358–385.</ref> ABDT argues that individuals face overwhelming anxiety which leads to the symptoms of PTSD including re-experiencing, hyper-arousal, avoidance and disassociation.<ref name="ABDT">Pyszczynski, T., & Kesebir, P. Anxiety buffer disruption theory: a terror management account of posttraumatic stress disorder. Anxiety, Stress, & Coping. Vol 24. No. 1, Jan. 2011, 3–26.</ref><ref name="samandmaxfield">Abdollahi, A., Maxfield, M., Pyszczynski, T, & Luxzezynski, A. Posttraumatic stress reactions as a disruption in anxiety-buffer functioning: dissociation and responses to mortality salience as predictors of severity of posttraumatic symptoms. Psychological Trauma: Theory, Research, Practice and Policy. 2011, Vol. 3, Nov. 4, 329–341.</ref> The dissociation causes atypical responses to mortality salience compared with individuals who do not suffer from an anxiety buffer disruption <ref name="mainpaper" /> When the anxiety buffer disruption is mild, exaggerated coping responses, such as rejecting or taking offense at other cultures, is expected. When the anxiety buffer disruption is severe, there can be a total breakdown of coping mechanisms.<ref name="studyone">Abdollahi, A., Pyszczynski, T., Maxfield, M., & Luszczynska, A. (2011). Posttraumatic stress reactions as a disruption in anxiety-buffer functioning: Dissociation and responses to mortality salience as predictors of severity of posttraumatic symptoms. Psychological Trauma: Theory, Research, Practice, and Policy, 3(4), 329.</ref> The theory was proposed by [[Tom Pyszczynski]] and Pelin Kesebir.<ref name="mainpaper"/>
== Origins ==
=== Shattered assumption theory === In 1992, Janoff-Bulman delineated a theory of trauma response ([[Shattered Assumptions Theory]]). Janoff-Bulman posits that humans have basic assumptions about the world in which they live, based on the belief that the world is a benevolent and meaningful place and that the individual has self-worth.<ref name="mills">Mills, M. (2010) Shattered assumptions? A prospective study: The impact of trauma of global beliefs and adjustment. Doctoral Dissertations. Paper AAI3447452. http://digitalcommons.uconn.edu/dissertations/AAI3447452.</ref> These assumptions give the individual the illusion that they have a measure of control on their own lives as well as a feeling of invulnerability.<ref name="edmonson" /> When an individual faces a traumatic event, their deeply held beliefs that the world is a benevolent and meaningful place and that they have a worthy role in that world are shattered.<ref name="mills" /> The world is no longer benevolent or predictable. Terror management theory and anxiety buffer disruption theory have taken the concept one step further.
=== Anxiety buffer disruption theory === Anxiety buffer disruption theory not only focuses on the thoughts and emotions of an individual, but it also studies the behavior that results when terror management theory and shattered assumptions theory are examined together.<ref name="edmonson" /> Excessive anxiety experienced by post-traumatic stress disorder sufferers occurs because the events causing the post-traumatic stress disorder have demonstrated to these individuals that anxiety-buffering mechanisms are not capable of protecting them from death.<ref name="mainpaper" /> Individuals who have high levels of [[dissociation (psychology)|peritraumatic dissociation]] and low levels of [[self-efficacy]] coping, two indicators of post-traumatic stress disorder, have abnormal responses to reminders of death. These individuals in turn do not utilize the coping mechanisms that are typically used to remove the fear of death: culture, self-esteem, and interpersonal relationships. In fact, in individuals with post traumatic stress disorder, mortality salience coping mechanisms are viewed as worthless and perhaps are even seen to be detestable.<ref name="ABDT" />
=== Components of anxiety buffers ===
* '''Cultural Worldview''': Individuals who have post traumatic stress disorder will often reject their culture when provided with mortality salience triggers, the direct opposite of what terror management theory demonstrates to be true in those without post traumatic stress disorder.<ref name="ABDT" /> Cultural worldviews infuse life with structure, purpose and meaning. People maintain these fragile constructions by preferring the company of the like-minded. But when faced with a traumatic event, there are times when the horror cannot be assimilated into the framework of the person's existing cultural worldview.<ref name="mainpaper"/> * '''Self-Esteem''': Various studies demonstrate that individuals who have post traumatic stress disorder also have decreased self-esteem. Self-esteem cannot function well as an anxiety buffering system in those who have post traumatic stress disorder as the buffer is weakened in these individuals.<ref name="mainpaper" /> High self-esteem can displace defensive responses and buffer against the terror of mortality salience because it is a signal that the individual is living at the standard they should, based on their world view.<ref name="edmonson" /> Self-worth as the terror management theory suggests is an essential component of the existential anxiety- buffering system. PTSD is related to a breakdown in this system, and noted that veterans with past and present, or ongoing PTSD have shown to have lower self-esteem. According to ABDT this leaves this group particularly vulnerable to anxiety, since self-worth is an integral part of the individual’s anxiety- buffering mechanism. [1] * '''Close Relationships''': It is often mentioned that worldview and self-esteem affect ways in which our fears of death are buffered with ABDT. Close relationships also serve as a regulator of these fears. Previous studies hinted at that close relationships played a role in terror management, but they did not conceptualize, theoretically explain, or test the context of close relationships in Terror Management Theories.<ref name="florian">Florian, V., Mikulincer, M., & Hirschberger, G. (2002). The anxiety-buffering function of close relationships: evidence that relationship commitment acts as a terror management mechanism. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 82(4), 527.</ref> Close relationships seem to be a product of natural selection because of their reproductive and survival benefits, having reproductive benefits contribute to the survival of people’s genes through their offspring. Therefore, close relationships increase the likelihood of mating and brings about other survival skills like gathering food, finding shelter, environmental awareness, and protects offspring from dangers.<ref name="buss">Buss, D. M., & Schmitt, D. P. (1993). Sexual strategies theory: an evolutionary perspective on human mating. Psychological review, 100(2), 204.</ref> Love and belongingness are ranked over those of esteem and self- actualization.<ref name="maslow">Maslow, A. H., Frager, R., & Cox, R. (1970). Motivation and personality (Vol. 2). J. Fadiman, & C. McReynolds (Eds.). New York: Harper & Row.</ref> The formation and maintenance of close relationships have been recognized in both infants and adults as a source of regulating distress. It is also noted that self- esteem can also stem from close relationships. Based on these things it was assumed that formation and maintenance of close relationships may serve as a death- anxiety- buffering mechanism.<ref name="florian" />
Close relationships appear to have inoculating power against basic existential threats, which allows people to respond to these threats by fulfilling relational potentials. Second, it seems the sense of relationship commitment is shaped by not only perceived relational investment, gains, and potential alternatives, as well as the existential need of denial of death awareness. Third, it seems processes of terror management not only include worldview defenses to protect the self, but also promote commitment to significant others and the expansion of the self, provided by these relationships.<ref name="florian" />
An important finding is that close relationships may serve as a fundamental anxiety buffer. It appears close relationships not only protect individuals from concrete and actual threats or danger, but also offers a symbolic shield against the awareness of one’s finitude. Since the threat of death is inescapable, the support from those close to us make may make the thought of death more tolerable by giving meaning to our lives by being important to others.<ref name="florian" />
As other anxiety buffers, interpersonal relationships are damaged as well in individuals with post traumatic stress disorder. People with post traumatic stress disorder have higher rates of divorce, more difficulty with their children, are more prone to domestic violence, and are emotionally distant from loved ones. All of these are damaging and as a result, terror management cannot be accomplished through close interpersonal relationships.<ref name="mainpaper" />
== Anxiety buffer disruption theory studies ==
=== Posttraumatic stress reactions === A study looked at dissociation responses and PTSD in students who survived the [[2005 Zarand earthquake]] in Iran. The earthquake measured 6.4 on the Richter scale, killed more than 1,500 people and displaced more than 6,700 for two months or more. It looked at dissociation one month later then two years later to see if level of dissociation predicted PTSD.
Four weeks after the earthquake, researchers solicited for volunteers at local universities. All of the participants met the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|DSM-IV]] criterion for a Class A1 trauma. Many were wearing black mourning clothes or had injuries from the earthquake.
Three priming conditions were employed: mortality salience, earthquake or dental pain. The researchers then evaluated how the subjects felt toward foreign aid in the wake of the disaster. The results indicated that subjects with high dissociative tendencies showed no effect of mortality salience on attitudes toward the foreign aid. Subjects with low dissociative tendencies reacted as terror management theory predicts when confronted with mortality salience and thought of the earthquake.
Two years after the quake, the researchers returned and 172 of the original respondents participated. They predicted that subjects with high PTSD symptoms would have a disrupted worldview on both foreign aid and the [[Islam and clothing|Islamic dress code]]. They found a strong relationship between dissociation and subsequent PTSD symptom severity. Even after the passage of two years, subjects with high dissociative tendencies were still not defending against existential threats in a way typical for the population who has not experienced trauma.<ref name="studyone"/>
=== Extent of trauma exposure and PTSD symptom severity === 105 students of the University of Abidjan took the Post-Traumatic Stress Checklist-Civilian Version and then an opinion survey on the civil war in [[Cote d'Ivoire]]. Last, they took part in a word-completion task designed to measure their accessibility of death-related thoughts. This study, unlike previous studies related to terror management theory, looked at the subjects' thoughts of death as related to the war, a specific traumatic event.
In the [[Scientific control|control condition]], where subjects were asked to talk about their anxiety related to their worst exam, death thought accessibility was lower for those with higher levels of PTSD. This suggests that people suffering from strong PTSD repress thoughts of death. But when mortality was made salient, it provoked a marked increase in death thought accessibility for those with high PTSD. The results indicate that the anxiety buffer of death thought suppression under normal circumstances failed when subjects were reminded of the traumatic event.
A second experiment was conducted with 197 students of the University of Ajidjan where they evaluated exposure (proximity) to a traumatic event. In this case, it was geographical location to the civil war. The researchers hypothesized that subjects who lived where the fighting was more constant and intense would be more likely to increase their PTSD reports when mortality was made salient. Those who lived in an area of less conflict should not increase their reports of PTSD. As a form of defensive denial, the researchers predicted they might report lower levels of symptoms. As expected, subjects who had more exposure to war reported greater PTSD symptoms in the mortality salience condition.<ref name="tard">Chatard, A., Pyszczynski, T., Arndt, J., Selimbegović, L., Konan, P. N., & Van der Linden, M. (2012). Extent of trauma exposure and PTSD symptom severity as predictors of anxiety-buffer functioning. Psychological Trauma: Theory, Research, Practice, and Policy, 4(1), 47.</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Anxiety Buffer Disruption Theory}} [[Category:Attitude change]] [[Category:Death]] [[Category:Existential therapy]] [[Category:Psychological theories]]

/* Biography */the work's name is "The New York Times" using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2012}} '''Bernard d'Abrera''' (28 August 1940 – 13 January 2017) was an Australian [[entomological]] [[taxonomist]] and [[Philosophy of science|philosopher of science]], particularly noted for his books on true butterflies ([[Papilionoidea]]) and larger moths of the world ([[Saturniidae]] and [[Sphingidae]]). Referred to as one of the world's best-known [[lepidopterists]] by ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'',<ref>{{cite news |title=Museum's move puts butterfly world in a flutter |author=Charles Clover |newspaper=[[Daily Telegraph]]|page=5|date= 27 November 2004|accessdate=28 January 2018|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1477627/Museum-move-puts-butterfly-world-in-a-flutter.html}}</ref> his work since 1982 was openly critical of [[evolution]].
== Biography == Bernard d'Abrera was a graduate of the [[University of New South Wales]] in [[Sydney]], Australia. While at the university in 1964 he with a group of other students kidnapped an alligator from Taronga Zoo as a Foundation Day prank. Using 80 biology students as a shield, the group captured the animal in a bag and walked out through the turnstiles. The animal was returned after payment of a £100 ransom, which went towards establishing the first aboriginal scholarship of the University of New South Wales.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.recordkeeping.unsw.edu.au/historicalresources/onlineexhibitions/foundationday.html |title=University of New South Wales - Records and Archives Office - Foundation Day Exhibition |publisher=Recordkeeping.unsw.edu.au |date= |accessdate=2011-08-10}}</ref>
He received his [[Bachelor of Arts]] in 1965, with a double major in History & Philosophy of Science and History. He has a diploma in Education (Melbourne T.C., 1972).
D'Abrera spent over forty years photographing museum specimens of butterflies and moths, as well as identifying and cataloguing specimens around the world.<ref name=court>[http://www.uscfc.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/LETTOW.DABRERA081507.pdf Opinion and Order] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090514090656/http://www.uscfc.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/LETTOW.DABRERA081507.pdf |date=14 May 2009 }}, Retrieved August 2011</ref> He has also visited the [[Macleay Museum]]<ref>[http://www.usyd.edu.au/museums/pdfs_docs/macleay_news/cnews08.pdf ''Macleay Museum News''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070912024601/http://www.usyd.edu.au/museums/pdfs_docs/macleay_news/cnews08.pdf |date=12 September 2007 }}, usyd.edu.au. Retrieved August 2011</ref> in [[Sydney]]. He contributed his butterfly and moth photographs to other books not authored by him.<ref name=court /><ref>{{cite web|author=UK |url=http://www.nhbs.com/the_butterflies_of_the_malay_peninsula_tefno_5567.html&tab_tag=album |title=The Butterflies of the Malay Peninsula - AS Corbet and HM Pendlebury |publisher=NHBS |date= |accessdate=2011-08-10}}</ref>
The [[D'Abrera's tiger]], ''Parantica dabrerai'', an Indonesian butterfly species is named for him, as is ''[[Gnathothlibus dabrera]]'', a species of Indonesian moth.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sphin-sea.unibas.ch/SphinSEA/species%20pages/Gn_dabrera.htm |title=The Sphingidae of Southeast |publisher=Sphin-sea.unibas.ch |date= |accessdate=2011-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726051925/http://www.sphin-sea.unibas.ch/SphinSEA/species%20pages/Gn_dabrera.htm |archivedate=26 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 1978, d'Abrera helped uncover a smuggling ring on [[Papua New Guinea]] estimated to have earned at least $200,000 annually through the rare butterfly black market.<ref>{{cite news |title=Australian entomologist Bernard D'Abrera comments on network of smugglers and black marketeers|author=Sandra Salmans|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 April 1978|accessdate=7 December 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/04/19/archives/pinning-down-the-elusive-butterfly.html}}</ref>
In 1982, d'Abrera and his wife Lucilla founded Hill House Publishers, a publishing house based in [[Melbourne]] and [[London]], to publish among other things, his own work. In 1987, Hill House began a project to produce antiquarian facsimiles of the works of Victorian ornithologist [[John Gould]], based on the Natural History Museum's collection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hillhouse-publishers.com/about-hill-house-publishers |title=About Hill House Publishers | HillHouse |publisher=Hillhouse-publishers.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711171059/http://www.hillhouse-publishers.com/about-hill-house-publishers |archivedate=11 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Hill House also publishes authentic facsimiles of documents, prints, and antiquarian maps, including an atlas of the [[Dutch Indies]] for the Royal Dutch Geographical Society (KNAG - Gemilang, Landsmeer, 1990).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hillhouse-publishers.com/ | title=Official Website for Hill House Publishers | publisher=Hill House Publishers | accessdate=2007-11-26}}</ref> In a 2002 review of the book ''The Last Sorcerer: Echoes of the Rainforest'', ''[[Townsend Letter]]'' quoted from d'Abrera's 1984 book ''Butterflies of South America,'' writing: "The greatest number and diversity of insect and plant species occur in the Neotropics, a vast amount of which is still being discovered and described. Paradoxically, an almost equal amount of unknown creatures is being destroyed even before their discovery, because of the violent and ruthless destruction by civilized man of the complex miracles that make up the Neotropical ecosystem. History alone will pour out its wrathful judgement on these disgraceful goings-on, because contemporary man is too besotted with economic trivia to comprehend the consequences of his avaricious deeds. - Bernard D'Abrera Butterflies of South America (1984)."<ref>{{cite news |title=Adventure and Research in the Rainforest. (Book Corner). |author=Irene Alleger |newspaper=[[Townsend Letter for Doctors and Patients]] |date=1 February 2002|page=14}}</ref>
== Evolution== D'Abrera is listed as a signatory on the petition known as "[[A Scientific Dissent from Darwinism]]", a [[Discovery Institute intelligent design campaigns|campaign]] begun in 2001 by the [[Discovery Institute]]. D'Abrera is also a fellow of the pro-[[intelligent design]] organization, [[International Society for Complexity, Information and Design]].<ref>[http://www.iscid.org/fellows.php Society Fellows], [[International Society for Complexity, Information and Design]] official website.</ref>
D'Abrera was strongly opposed to the theory of evolution because in his view it is not a bona fide scientific theory. He describes evolution theory as "viscid, asphyxiating baggage" that requires "blind religious faith",<ref>''Concise Atlas of the Butterflies of the World'', Bernard d'Abrera, Hill House Publishers, Melb.& Lond., 2001, {{ISBN|978-0-947352-37-0}}.</ref> He believed it cannot be tested or demonstrated in any natural frame of reference, and therefore it may not be considered even a scientific postulate. The [[Objections to evolution#Unfalsifiability|objection that evolution is unfalsifiable]] has been widely rejected by the scientific community. D'Abrera's views on evolution and science have been criticised by Arthur Shapiro, who describes him as "profoundly anti-scientific — not ''un''scientific, but hostile to science."<ref>{{cite journal | title = (Review of) Bernard d'Abrera, Butterflies of the Holarctic Region, Part I | journal = Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera | first = Arthur | last = Shapiro | volume = 30 | issue = 1-2 | pages = 142–144| id = | url = http://lepidopteraresearchfoundation.org/journals/30/PDF30/30-142.pdf | accessdate = 2010-12-04}}</ref>
==Critical reception== [[Arthur Shapiro (ecologist)|Arthur Shapiro]], an [[evolutionary biologist]] and [[entomologist]] at the [[University of California at Davis]], described d'Abrera's books thus:<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Laufer | first1 = Peter. | title = The dangerous world of butterflies : the startling subculture of criminals, collectors, and conservationist | year = 2009 | publisher = Lyons Press | location = Guilford, Conn. | isbn = 1-59921-555-1 | page = 215 }}</ref> {{quote|Attention should be paid to their stupidities, their errors, their pig-headedness, their bad writing. The thing is, as I say in my reviews, they're absolutely indispensable. There's nothing else like them. If you're trying to identify exotic butterflies outside your geographic area, the primary and secondary literatures are so scattered and relatively inaccessible, you're out of hope. Big coffee table picture books are the only way to go. But if you're going to do that, at least get input from the people in the areas you cover geographically so you don't make an ass of yourself.}}
[[Philip James DeVries]] described him as "likely one of the best known Lepidopterists in the world, and therefore, an eminence on all things butterfly'.<ref>[http://peabody.research.yale.edu/jls/pdfs/2000s/2003/2003-57%281%2975-DeVries.pdf Peabody research] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807221057/http://peabody.research.yale.edu/jls/pdfs/2000s/2003/2003-57%281%2975-DeVries.pdf |date=7 August 2011 }}, Retrieved August 2011</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.hillhouse-publishers.com Hill House Publishers.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070930163030/http://www.learnaboutbutterflies.com/Bernard%20d%27Abrera.htm ''Bernard d'Abrera - a brief biography''], Bernard d'Abrera 2007, "''Learn About Butterflies''" website, Adrian Hoskins. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080513001927/http://www.iscid.org/bernard-dabrera.php ''Bernard d'Abrera''], [[International Society for Complexity, Information and Design]] official website. *[http://lepidopteraresearchfoundation.org/journals/23/PDF23/23-169.pdf Reviews of ''Butterflies of South America''], Thomas C. Emmel, [[Arthur Shapiro (ecologist)|Arthur Shapiro]], ''Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera'', 23:172-173.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:D'Abrera, Bernard}} [[Category:Australian entomologists]] [[Category:Australian naturalists]] [[Category:Australian taxonomists]] [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:Australian nature writers]] [[Category:Australian publishers (people)]] [[Category:Christian creationists]] [[Category:Intelligent design advocates]] [[Category:Lepidopterists]] [[Category:University of New South Wales alumni]]

[[File:1.26 Denver Biennial Sculpture.jpeg|right|thumb|258x258px|[[Janet Echelman]]: [[1.26 (Sculpture)|1.26 Sculpture]], 2010 Biennial of the Americas]] The '''Biennial of the Americas''' is an international [[festival]] of [[Thought|ideas]], [[art]], and [[culture]] hosted in [[Denver]], [[Colorado]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Biennial of the Americas Website|url=http://www.biennialoftheamericas.org/experience/|publisher=Biennial of the Americas}}</ref> According to its website, the Biennial strives to provide a platform for people from across the region to examine major issues impacting life in the [[Americas]]. With three main themes of ideas, art, and culture, the Biennial is designed to bring together experts and leaders from across [[North America|North]], [[South America|South]], and [[Central America]] in a variety of formats that include panel discussions, peer-to-peer [[workshop]]s, [[Art exhibition|art exhibits]], outdoor architectural installations, and public [[parties]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Rinaldi|first=Ray Mark|title=Denver Biennial Brings Butterflies, Beer (and Tina Brown) next month|url=http://www.denverpost.com/entertainment/ci_23452599/denver-biennial-brings-butterflies-beer-and-tina-brown#ixzz2Wa3mp12E|publisher=The Denver Post}}</ref>
:
== 2013 Festival ==
: The 2013 Biennial of the Americas took place in Denver, CO from July 16- September 2. The upcoming Biennial of the Americas opening week will take place from July 14–19, 2015. The 2013 opening week began on July 16 with the theme “Unleashing Human Potential: Reinventing Communities, Business, and Education”.<ref>{{cite web|last=Finance |first=Yahoo |title=Yahoo Finance Announcement |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/2013-biennial-americas-announces-free-170000483.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130707002412/http://finance.yahoo.com/news/2013-biennial-americas-announces-free-170000483.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 July 2013 |accessdate=2 July 2013 }}</ref> 'Ideas' events ran through the closing symposium on July 19, but art and cultural pieces remained on display through Labor Day, September 2.
=== Ideas ===
: Speakers during the inaugural week (July 16–19) included:<ref>{{cite news|last=Release|first=Press|title=Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/article/PR-CO-20130613-908776.html|accessdate=2 July 2013|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=June 13, 2013}}</ref> : '''July 16: Reinventing Communities, Business, and Education''' : * Moderator: [[Tina Brown]], Editor-in-Chief of the [[Newsweek Daily Beast Company]] * Google Executive Chairman [[Eric Schmidt]] * Former Mexican Ambassador to the United States, [[Arturo Sarukhan]] * Colorado Governor [[John Hickenlooper]] * Liberty Media Chairman [[John Malone]] : : '''July 17: Reinventing Communities and How we Live''' : * Moderator: [[Arianna Huffington]], Chair, President, and Editor-in-Chief of [[The Huffington Post]] * [[The Nature Conservancy]] Chief Scientist Peter Kareiva * Colombian Ambassador to the United States, [[Carlos Urrutia (Colombian diplomat)|Carlos Urrutia]] * Former CEO of The Panama Canal Authority, [[Alberto Aleman|Alberto Alemán Zubieta]] * Suncor Energy President and CEO Steve Williams * Duke Energy Chairman, President and CEO [[Jim Rogers]] : : '''July 18: Reinventing Business as Usual''' : * Moderator: [[Don Tapscott]] of Moxie Insight * Case Foundation CEO [[Jean Case]] * Qualcomm CEO [[Paul E. Jacobs|Paul Jacobs]] * SESC São Paulo Director Danilo Santos de Miranda * [[Inter-American Development Bank]] Executive VP and COO Julie T. Katzman * [[Morgan Stanley]] Latin-American Chairman Chris Harland : : '''July 19: Reinventing Education for the Global Market''' : * Moderator: [[Patricia Janiot]], Senior Anchor at [[CNN Español]] * [[US Secretary of Education]] [[Arne Duncan]] * Netflix CEO [[Reed Hastings]] * [[Coursera]] Co-Founder [[Daphne Koller]] * [[Discovery Communications]] Executive Chairman [[John Hendricks]] : :
=== Art ===
: : Along with recruiting high-profile speakers, the Biennial commissions major artistic exhibitions throughout the city of Denver. Artists and architects from across the Americas participate in the programming.:<ref>{{cite web|title=Biennial of the Americas 2013 Draft Urbanism|url=http://www.e-flux.com/announcements/2013-draft-urbanism/|publisher=E-flux}}</ref> The Biennial of the Americas’ 2013 exhibition, Draft Urbanism, was curated by Carson Chan, Gaspar Libedinsky, Paul Andersen, and Cortney Stell.<ref>{{cite web|title=Four Curators Elaborate the 2013 Biennial of the Americas, Draft Urbanism...|url=http://www.biennialfoundation.org/2013/06/four-curators-elaborate-the-2013-biennial-of-the-americas-draft-urbanism-that-brings-together-artists-and-architects-from-across-the-americas-to-examine-our-evolving-relationship-with-the-urban-fabr/|publisher=Biennial Foundation}}</ref> The exhibition brought together artists and architects from across the Americas to create site-specific art and architectural installations throughout Downtown Denver and in the historic McNichols Building. The exhibition explored the many meanings of the word “draft,” looking at the ideas of iteration, process, and the ever-changing urban fabric. In addition to last year's Draft Urbanism, the Biennial of the Americas will highlight Denver’s cultural offerings with featured exhibitions, films, public parties, performances, and other events intended to explore the various cultures of the Americas during the upcoming festival as well.:<ref>{{cite web|last=Forbes|first=Alexander|title=Curator Carson Chan on Serving Up 2013's Beer-Themed Biennial of the Americas|url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/898949/curator-carson-chan-on-serving-up-2013s-beer-themed-biennial|publisher=Blouin Art Info}}</ref>
=== Culture ===
: The Biennial also organized a series of public festivals throughout Denver in tandem with organizations such as the Denver Museum of Contemporary Art, Arts and Venues Denver, the Center for Visual Arts, the [[Clyfford Still Museum]], the [[Colorado Ballet]], the Colorado Symphony, the Denver Architectural Foundation, the [[Denver Art Museum]], the Denver Botanical Gardens, Denver Digerati, the Denver Film Society, the [[Denver International Airport]] Art Gallery, the [[Denver Museum of Nature and Science]], the Mexican Cultural Center, Museo de las Americas, Platte Forum, Santa Fe Art District, Su Teatro, Redline, Rino Arts District, and [[Rocky Mountain College of Art and Design]].:<ref>{{cite web|title=Biennial of the Americas Cultural Programming|url=http://www.biennialoftheamericas.org/experience/cultural-programming/}}</ref> * July 16: Art Opening: Draft Urbanism<ref>{{cite web|title=RMCAD Faculty, Staff and Alumni to Take Part in the Biennial of the Americas|url=http://www.rmcad.edu/news/rmcad-faculty-staff-and-alumni-take-part-biennial-americas|publisher=Rocky Mountain College of Art}}</ref> * July 17: Canada Night at Sustainability Park<ref>{{cite web|title=Redline: Imagined Realities Event Page |url=http://redlineart.org/art/events/exhibitions/imagined-realities.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304002158/http://redlineart.org/art/events/exhibitions/imagined-realities.html |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref> * July 18: Mexico Night! * July 19: Denver Night!<ref>{{cite web|title=Biennial of the Americas Public Festivals|url=http://www.biennialoftheamericas.org/experience/public-festivals/}}</ref>
Public festivals will also be a part of the 2015 Biennial of the Americas.
== History ==
:[[File:John W. Hickenlooper World Economic Forum 2013.jpg|right|thumb|Governor John Hiickenlooper]] Before becoming governor, John Hickenlooper served as the Mayor of Denver from 2003-2011. During that time he developed a vision for an event that would celebrate the ideas and cultures of the Americas, believing that such an event would highlight Denver as a hub for bipartisan discussion. This idea developed into what is now the Biennial of the Americas.<ref>{{cite web|title=Biennial of the Americas FAQ|url=http://www.biennialoftheamericas.org/biennial-information/faqs/|publisher=Biennial of the Americas}}</ref> During the inaugural Biennial of the Americas in 2010, the Biennial welcomed national and international visitors during a month-long celebration. Programming included free musical performances by artists such as Juana Molina, and a number of artistic exhibitions across Denver.<ref>{{cite web|last=Korolowicz|first=Kristin|title=2010 Biennial of the Americas|url=http://www.artlurker.com/2010/08/2010-biennial-of-the-americas/|publisher=Art Lurker|accessdate=3 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Civic Center Event Page|url=http://www.civiccenterconservancy.org/history-2010-denver-biennial-of-the-americas_24.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Curator for July's Biennial of the Americas Knows Time is Short|url=http://www.denverpost.com/entertainmentlastold/ci_14631645|publisher=The Denver Post | first=Kyle|last=MacMillan}}</ref> Speakers participated in roundtable discussions that ranged widely by subject. Topics included education, philanthropy, [[climate and energy]] change, health, public and private collaboration, poverty reduction, trade, and women as “Drivers in the New Economy”.<ref>{{cite web|title=Remarks by Secretary of Labor Hilda L. Solis|url=http://www.dol.gov/_sec/media/speeches/20100707_Women.htm|publisher=United States Department of Labor}}</ref> Roundtable participants included: : : * [[Alejandro Toledo]], former president of the Republic of Peru : * [[Fernando de la Mora (politician)|Fernanado de la Rúa]], former president of the Argentine Republic : * [[Gustavo Noboa]], former president of the Republic of Ecuador : * [[Hipólito Mejía]], former president of the Dominican Republic : * [[Nicolás Ardito Barletta]], former president of the Republic of Panama : * [[Rodrigo Borja Cevallos|Rodrigo Borja Cavallos]], former president of the Republic of Ecuador : * [[Vinicio Cerezo]], former president of the Republic of Guatemala : *Arturo Fermandois, former Ambassador of Chile to the United States : *[[Arturo Sarukhan]], former Ambassador of Mexico to the United States : *[[Carolina Barco]], former Ambassador of Colombia to the United States : *Francisco Villagran, Ambassador of Guatemala to the United States : *[[Gary Doer]], Ambassador of Canada to the United States : *Jaime Alemán, former Ambassador of Panama to the United States : *[[Hugo Llorens]], former Ambassador of the United States to Honduras : *[[Luis Valdivieso]], former Ambassador of Chile to the United States : *[[Mauro Vieira]], Ambassador of Brazil to the United States : *[[Thomas A. Shannon, Jr.|Thomas Shannon]], Ambassador of the United States to Brazil : *Vilma Martinez, Ambassador of the United States to Argentina : *[[William Brownfield]], Ambassador of the United States to Colombia : : Artists that participated in the 2010 Biennial of the Americas included Felipe Mujica, [[Brigida Baltar]], Jeronimo Hagerman, Lucia Koch, Santiago Cucullo, Clark Richert, Ronald Rael, Virginia San Fratello, Teddy Cruz, Nicolas de Moncheaux, Alexis Rochas, Joseph Shaeffer and Estafonia Peñafiel.<ref>{{cite web|title=Special Edition: Biennial of the Americas 2010 |url=http://www.icosa.co/special-edition-the-biennial/ |publisher=Icosa Magazine |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304053532/http://www.icosa.co/special-edition-the-biennial/ |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref>

{{for|the specific book by Gunther Pauli|The Blue Economy}} {{Economics sidebar}}
'''Blue economy''' is a term in [[economics]] relating to the exploitation and preservation of the marine environment. Its scope of interpretation varies among organizations.
==Definitions== According to the [[World Bank]],<ref>{{cite web|title=What is the Blue Economy?|url=http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/infographic/2017/06/06/blue-economy|website=THE WORLD BANK|accessdate=14 May 2018|date=6 June 2017}}</ref> the blue economy is the "sustainable use of ocean resources for economic growth, improved livelihoods, and jobs while preserving the health of ocean ecosystem."
[[European Commission]] defines it as "All economic activities related to oceans, seas and coasts. It covers a wide range of interlinked established and emerging sectors."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2018|title=The 2018 Annual Economic Report on EU Blue Economy|url=https://ec.europa.eu/maritimeaffairs/sites/maritimeaffairs/files/2018-annual-economic-report-on-blue-economy_en.pdf|journal=European Union|volume=|pages=5|via=}}</ref>
The [[Commonwealth of Nations]] considers it "an emerging concept which encourages better stewardship of our ocean or 'blue' resources."<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://thecommonwealth.org/blue-economy|title=Blue economy {{!}} The Commonwealth|last=(http://www.hydrant.co.uk)|first=Site designed and built by Hydrant|website=thecommonwealth.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
[[Conservation International]] adds that "blue economy also includes economic benefits that may not be marketed, such as carbon storage, coastal protection, cultural values and biodiversity."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blog.conservation.org/2018/03/what-on-earth-is-the-blue-economy/?gclid=Cj0KCQjwl9zdBRDgARIsAL5Nyn3xGXHsApcgFjjO6CvN0Zg602NYYuJw2LPvqa_nDpKKxPtNDJWQxLYaAvSLEALw_wcB|title=What on Earth is the ‘blue economy’? – Human Nature - Conservation...|last=Bertazzo|first=Sophie|date=2018-03-07|work=Human Nature – Conservation International Blog|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
[[The Center for the Blue Economy]] says "it is now a widely used term around the world with three related but distinct meanings- the overall contribution of the oceans to economies, the need to address the environmental and ecological sustainability of the oceans, and the ocean economy as a growth opportunity for both developed and developing countries."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.middlebury.edu/institute/academics/centers-initiatives/center-blue-economy/about/history|title=Our History and Methodology|website=Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
[[World Wildlife Fund]] begins its report<ref name=":1">{{cite book|url=http://d2ouvy59p0dg6k.cloudfront.net/downloads/15_1471_blue_economy_6_pages_final.pdf|title=Principles for a Sustainable BLUE ECONOMY|last=|first=|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|year=|isbn=|location=|page=2|pages=|accessdate=14 May 2018}}</ref> ''Principles for a Sustainable BLUE ECONOMY'' with two senses given to this term: "For some, blue economy means the use of the sea and its resources for sustainable economic development. For others, it simply refers to any economic activity in the maritime sector, whether sustainable or not."
As the WWF reveals in its purpose of the report, there is still no widely accepted definition of the term blue economy despite increasing high-level adoption of it as a concept and as a goal of policy-making and investment.<ref name=":1" />
== Related terms ==
=== Ocean economy === A related term of blue economy is ocean economy and we see some organizations using the two terms interchangeably. However, these two terms represent different concepts. Ocean economy simply deals with the use of ocean resources and is strictly aimed at empowering the economic system of ocean.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.examrace.com/Current-Affairs/NEWS-Blue-Economy-Versus-Ocean-Economy.htm|title=Blue Economy versus Ocean Economy- Translation in Hindi, Kannada, Malayalam, Marathi, Punjabi, Sindhi, Sindhi, Tamil, Telgu - Examrace|last=Examrace|website=www.examrace.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> Blue economy goes beyond viewing the ocean economy solely as a mechanism for economic growth.<ref name=":0" /> It focuses on the sustainability of ocean for economic growth. Therefore, blue economy encompasses ecological aspects of the ocean along with economic aspects.
=== Green economy === The [[green economy]] is defined as an economy that aims at reducing environmental risks, and that aims for sustainable development without degrading the environment. It is closely related with [[ecological economics]]. Therefore, blue economy is a part of green economy. During Rio+20 Summit in June 2012, Pacific small island developing states stated that, for them, "a green economy was in fact a blue economy".<ref name="Really">{{cite web|url=http://wwf.panda.org/homepage.cfm?249111/What-a-blue-economy-really-is|title=What a 'blue economy' really is – WWF’s perspective|date=10 July 2015|website=WWF|accessdate=14 May 2018}}</ref>
=== Blue growth === A related term is blue growth, which means "support to the growth of the maritime sector in a sustainable way."<ref name="Commission">{{cite web|title=BLUE GROWTH|url=http://ec.europa.eu/assets/mare/infographics/|website=Mare|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=14 May 2018|date=2014}}</ref> The term is adopted by the European Union as an integrated maritime policy to achieve the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/maritimeaffairs/policy/blue_growth_en|title=Blue growth - Maritime Affairs - European Commission|last=Anonymous|date=2016-09-28|website=Maritime Affairs - European Commission|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>
==Potential== On top of the traditional ocean activities such as fisheries, tourism and maritime transport, blue economy entails emerging industries including renewable energy, aquaculture, seabed extractive activities and marine biotechnology and bioprospecting.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2017|title=The Potential of the Blue Economy : Increasing Long-term Benefits of the Sustainable Use of Marine Resources for Small Island Developing States and Coastal Least Developed Countries|url=https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/bitstream/handle/10986/26843/115545.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y|journal=World Bank|volume=|pages=ix|via=}}</ref> Blue economy also attempts to embrace ocean ecosystem services that are not captured by the market but provide significant contribution to economic and human activity. They include carbon sequestration, coastal protection, waste disposal, and the existence of biodiversity.<ref name=":2" />
The 2015 WWF briefing puts the value of key ocean assets over US$24 trillion.<ref name="Really" /> Fisheries are now overexploited, but there is still plenty of room for aquaculture<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fujita|first1=Rod|title=FAO Reports 87% of the World’s Fisheries are Overexploited or Fully Exploited|url=http://blogs.edf.org/edfish/2012/07/11/fao-reports-87-of-the-worlds-fisheries-are-overexploited-or-fully-exploited/|website=FAO|accessdate=14 May 2018|date=11 July 2012}}</ref> and offshore wind power.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wind EUROPE|last2=BVGassociates|title=Unleashing Europe’s offshore wind potential|date=June 2017|location=Brussels, Belgium|page=16|url=https://windeurope.org/wp-content/uploads/files/about-wind/reports/Unleashing-Europes-offshore-wind-potential.pdf|accessdate=14 May 2018}}</ref> Aquaculture is the fastest growing food sector with the supply of 58 percent of fish to global markets.<ref name=":2" /> Aquaculture is vital to food security of the poorest countries especially. Only in the [[European Union]] the blue economy employed 3,362,510 people in 2014.<ref name="Commission" />
== Challenges == The World Bank specifies three challenges that limit the potential to develop a blue economy.<ref name=":2" />
# Current economic trends that have been rapidly degrading ocean resources. # The lack of investment in human capital for employment and development in innovative blue economy sectors. # Inadequate care for marine resources and ecosystem services of the oceans.
==Sectors== * [[Aquaculture]] (fish farms, but also [[algaculture]]) * Maritime [[biotechnology]] *[[Bioprospecting]] * [[Fishing]] * [[Maritime transport]] * Maritime and coastal [[tourism]] * [[Mineral resources]] * [[Offshore oil]] and gas * [[Offshore wind power]] (also [[Tidal power|tidal]] and [[Wave power|wave]]) * [[Shipbuilding]] and [[Ship repair]]<ref name=Commission/> *[[Desalination]] *[[Carbon sequestration]] *Coastal protection *Waste disposal *Existence of biodiversity
==See also== * [[Algae fuel]] * [[Circular economy]] * [[Cruise ship]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Good Article}} {{Infobox museum | name = Croatian Natural History Museum | native_name = Hrvatski prirodoslovni muzej | native_name_lang = hr | image = Hrvatski prirodoslovni muzej.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = Entrance to the Croatian Natural History Museum | coordinates = {{coord|45.817115|15.972314|region:HR-21_type:landmark_scale:4000_region:HR-21|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | former_name = National Museum | established = {{Start date|1846|10|09|df=y}} | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | location = Demetrova 1, [[Zagreb]], Croatia | type = [[Natural history museum]] | accreditation = Croatian Museum Council | key_holdings = [[Krapina remains]] ([[Neanderthal]]) | collections = {{Plainlist| * [[Botanical]] * [[Geological]]-[[palaeontological]] * [[Mineralogy|Mineralogical]]-[[petrographic]] * [[Zoological]]}} | collection_size = 2 million objects | visitors = 32,040 (2012)<ref name="mdc visits">{{cite web |title=Posjet muzejima u Hrvatskoj 2012. g. |url=http://www.mdc.hr/UserFiles/Image/projekti/statistika/posjecenost_2012_prema_broju_posjetitelja_.pdf|publisher=Museum Documentation Centre | location=Zagreb |language=hr|format=PDF |accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> | founder = | director = Tatjana Vlahović | website = {{URL|hpm.hr}} }}
The '''Croatian Natural History Museum''' ({{lang-hr|Hrvatski prirodoslovni muzej}}) is the oldest and biggest [[natural history museum]] and the main body for natural history research, preservation and collection in [[Croatia]].<ref name="mdc museum mission">{{cite web |title=Poslanje muzeja |url=http://hvm.mdc.hr/hrvatski-prirodoslovni-muzej,600%3aZAG/hr/info/|publisher=Museum Documentation Centre |location=Zagreb |language=hr |accessdate=10 August 2015}}</ref> Located on [[Dimitrije Demeter]] Street in [[Gradec, Zagreb|Gornji Grad]], one of the oldest neighbourhoods of the Croatian capital [[Zagreb]], it owns one of the biggest museum collections in Croatia, with over 2 million artefacts, including over 1.1 million animal specimens. It was founded in 1846 as the "National Museum". The National Museum was later split up into five museums, three of which were in 1986 merged as departments of the newly named Croatian Natural History Museum. The museum contains a large scientific library open to the public, and publishes the first Croatian natural history scientific journal, ''Natura Croatica''.
The permanent display of the Croatian Natural History Museum consists of mineralogical, petrographical and zoological collections, as well as two permanent exhibits in the [[atrium (architecture)|atrium]]: the Rock Map of Croatia and the Geological Pole. It is home to the remains of the [[Krapina remains|Neanderthal from Krapina]].
== History == [[File:Hrvatski prirodoslovni muzej (ploca).jpg|thumb|left|Museum plaque]] The history of the Croatian Natural History Museum begins with the founding of the so-called "National Museum" ({{lang|hr|Narodni muzej}}) on 10 September 1846, the first museum for historic and pre-historic objects related to Croatia.<ref name="informatica museologica" /> In 1867, it was moved to its current address.<ref name="mdc about museum">{{cite web |title=About the museum |url=http://hvm.mdc.hr/croatian-natural-history-museum,600%3aZAG/en/info/|publisher=Museum Documentation Centre| location=Zagreb |accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref> The National Museum grew and was split into five new museums by the end of the 19th century. Three of them covered natural history: the Croatian National Zoological Museum ({{lang|hr|Hrvatski narodni zoološki muzej}}), the Geological–Palaeontological Museum ({{lang|hr|Geološko-paleontološki muzej}}) and the Mineralogical–Petrographic Museum ({{lang|hr|Mineraloško-petrografski muzej}}). All three were housed in the same building on Demeter Street 1, and, in 1986, united into the Croatian Natural History Museum.<ref name="informatica museologica">{{cite journal |last1=Balabanić |first1=Josip |last2=Ćaleta|first2=Darija |last3=Vuković |first3=Marijana |title=Prirodoslovni muzeji i znanstveni rad |journal=Informatica Museologica |date=July 1999 |volume=29 |issue=3–4 |page=47–54 |url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=210954 |accessdate=6 August 2015 |trans-title=Natural History Museums and Scientific Research |publisher=Museum Documentation Centre |location=Zagreb |language=hr |issn=1849-4277}}</ref>
The museum's current building was earlier home to [[Amadeo's theatre]], the first theatre in Zagreb.<ref name="informatica museologica" /><ref name="museum beginnings">{{cite web |title=Postanak i ustrojstvo muzeja |url=http://hpm.web.link2.hr/O%20muzeju./Postanak%20i%20ustrojstvo%20muzeja|publisher=Croatian Natural History Museum |language=hr |accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> Formed in 1797 by [[Antal Amade de Varkony]], the prefect of [[Zagreb County (former)|Zagreb County]], it operated until 1834. In 2000, Amadeo's theatre was revived as a yearly summer series of theatrical plays entitled ''[[Amadeo Theatre and Music Company|Scena Amadeo]]'' ("Amadeo Scene") held in the museum atrium.<ref name="about museum">{{cite web |title=O muzeju |url=http://hpm.web.link2.hr/O%20muzeju./O%20muzeju|publisher=Croatian Natural History Museum |language=hr |accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="vecernji amadeo">{{cite web |title=Scena Amadeo za dobar večernji provod u Prirodoslovnom muzeju |url=http://www.vecernji.hr/kazaliste/scena-amadeo-za-dobar-vecernji-provod-u-prirodoslovnom-muzeju-306999|website=[[Večernji list]] |language=hr |accessdate=6 August 2015 |date=3 July 2011}}</ref>
== Library == The museum is home to a large scientific library open to the public. Its oldest books were printed in 17th-century Italy, and includes works by [[Ulisse Aldrovandi]], [[Niccolò Gualtieri]] and [[Carl Linné]].<ref name=library>{{cite web |title=Knjižnica |url=http://hpm.web.link2.hr/Knji%C5%BEnica.|publisher=Croatian Natural History Museum |language=hr |accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="im library history">{{cite journal |last1=Ćaleta|first1=Darija |title=Iz povijesti knjižnice Hrvatskoga prirodoslovnog muzeja |url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=210993&lang=en |journal=Informatica Museologica |date=February 1999 |volume=29|issue=1–2 |pages=45–50 |accessdate=14 August 2015|trans-title=From the history of the library of the Croatian Natural History Museum|publisher=Museum Documentation Centre|location=Zagreb |language=hr |issn=1849-4277|format=PDF}}</ref> The library was founded in 1868 by a newly appointed museum director, [[Spiridon Brusina]]. Starting from a meager corpus acquired from the [[National and University Library in Zagreb|National Library]], including only three books on zoology, Brusina traveled throughout then-[[Austria-Hungary]] in order to acquire books. In 1875, the museum acquired the large library and natural history collection of [[Francesco Lanza]], a physician and archaeologist from [[Split, Croatia|Split]], Croatia. Brusina retired in 1901, reporting a collection 1,800 works in 3,948 volumes three years earlier. In 1928, it was recorded that the library held 5,838 books in 9,901 volumes. As the library was not professionally maintained during the [[Croatian War of Independence]] or inventoried since, it is not known how many titles it holds. A 1999 estimate is 30,000 volumes and 13,100 [[monograph]]s.<ref name="im library history" />
== Journals == In 1885, Brusina led a successful initiative to publish ''The Journal of the Croatian Natural History Society'' ({{lang|hr|Glasnik Hrvatskoga naravoslovnoga družtva}}).<ref name="im library history" /> The journal is published since 1972 under the title ''Periodicum biologorum'', and focuses on [[biology]] and [[biomedicine]], [[forestry]] and [[biotechnology]].<ref name="im library history" /><ref name="hrcak pb">{{cite web |title=Periodicum biologorum |url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/pb|website=Hrčak|publisher=[[University of Zagreb]] |accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> In 1992, the museum began publishing ''Natura Croatica'', a peer-reviewed biological and geological academic journal.<ref name="natura croatica">{{cite web |title=Natura Croatica |url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/natura-croatica?lang=en|website=Hrčak|publisher=[[University of Zagreb]] |accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> The natural history journal was the first of its kind in Croatia, despite the existence of seven natural history museums.<ref name="informatica museologica" /> The journal is published quarterly in English, and reviewed by both Croatian and foreign scholars.<ref name="im library history" />
== Holdings == [[File:Primorska i gorska Hrvatska.JPG|thumb|upright|Rock samples from [[Dalmatia|Littoral Croatia]] and [[Gorski Kotar]] region arranged by age]] The museum is divided into Mineralogical–Petrographical, Geological–Palaeontological, Zoological and Botanical Departments. The first three are successors to the National Museum's 19th-century offspring museums, while the Botanical Department was established in 1990.<ref name="informatica museologica" />
The museum's holdings number over 2 million rocks, minerals, fossils, and other artefacts collected all over the country. The zoological collection consists of 1,135,000 animal specimens, including a [[tissue bank]] for [[DNA analysis]].<ref name="about museum" /><ref name=mdc>{{cite web |title=Croatian Natural History Museum |url=http://hvm.mdc.hr/croatian-natural-history-museum,600%3AZAG/en/info/|publisher=Museum Documentation Centre |location=Zagreb |accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> It also holds the [[Krapina remains|remains]] of the [[Neanderthal]] man found near [[Krapina]] by [[Dragutin Gorjanović-Kramberger]], a former director of the National Museum. The original remains are held in the museum's [[safe|vault]], while a replica is being exhibited in the Krapina museum.<ref name="jutarnji krapina man">{{cite web |last1=Sutlić|first1=Korana |title=Sve tajne zbirke Krapinca o kojoj izvještavaju CNN i New York Times |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/sve-tajne-zbirke-krapinca-o-kojoj-izvjestavaju-cnn-i-new-york-times/1323218/|website=[[Jutarnji list]] |accessdate=6 August 2015 |language=hr |date=31 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="jutarnji vučedol dove">{{cite web |last1=Sutlić|first1=Korana |title=Vučedolska golubica ipak se ne vraća kući |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/vucedolska-golubica-ipak-se-ne-vraca-kuci/1319477/|website=[[Jutarnji list]] |language=hr |accessdate=6 August 2015 |date=25 March 2015}}</ref>
The museum's permanent display encompasses mineralogical and petrographical collections,<ref name="min-petr collection">{{cite web |title=Mineraloško petrografski postav |url=http://hpm.web.link2.hr/Stalni%20postav/Mineralo%C5%A1ko%20petrografski%20postav|publisher=Croatian Natural History Museum |language=hr |accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> as well as a collection of animals, the bulk of which dates back to the 19th century.<ref name="zoological collection">{{cite web |title=Zoološki postav |url=http://hpm.web.link2.hr/Stalni%20postav/Zoolo%C5%A1ki%20postav|publisher=Croatian Natural History Museum |language=hr |accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> The zoological collection is on the second floor of the museum. It includes the skeleton of a [[Mediterranean monk seal]], a [[basking shark]] native to the [[Adriatic Sea]] and an [[Atlantic puffin]], a bird today native to the Arctic area, which is believed to have nested in the Adriatic in the 19th century.<ref name="zoological collection" />
The mineralogical and petrographical collections are divided into three exhibitions. "From a Collection to a Museum" ({{lang|hr|Od zbirke do muzeja}}) showcases the work of Croatian mineralogists and petrographers through history, including a [[geological map]] of [[Moslavačka gora]] in central Croatia by [[Ljudevit Vukotinović]], as well as the work of [[Đuro Pilar]], one of the first Croatian academic geologists. "The Empire of Minerals" ({{lang|hr|Carstvo minerala}}) displays a collection of minerals assembled by location of discovery, including collections of [[agate]] from [[Lepoglava]] and [[opal]], [[gemstone]]s rare in Croatia. "Rocky Planet Earth" ({{lang|hr|Stjenoviti planet Zemlja}}) is organized by [[list of rock types|rock types]], and also contains [[meteorite]]s, [[lava]] from [[Vesuvius]] and [[speleothem]]s. In 2014, the exhibitions were made accessible to blind people.<ref name="min-petr collection" />
The [[atrium (architecture)|atrium]] of the museum contains two exhibits: the Rock Map of Croatia (''Kamenospisna karta Hrvatske'') and the Geological Pole (''Geološki stup''). The Rock Map of Croatia is a [[mosaic]] map assembled from various pieces of rock found in Croatia into the country's shape.<ref name="mdc about museum hr">{{cite web |title=O muzeju |url=http://hvm.mdc.hr/hrvatski-prirodoslovni-muzej,600%3aZAG/hr/info/#|publisher=Museum Documentation Centre |location=Zagreb |accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=dalje.hr>{{cite web |last1=Kovač|first1=Ivan |title=Grad ipak pristao dati parking-mjesta muzejima |url=http://dalje.com/hr-zagreb/grad-ipak-pristao-dati-parking-mjesta-muzejima/168387|website=Dalje.hr |language=hr |accessdate=8 August 2015 |date=31 July 2008}}</ref>
== Exhibitions == [[File:Špiljski lav 1.JPG|thumbnail|left|Skull of a Croatian [[Panthera leo spelaea|cave lion]], exhibited in the Croatian Natural History Museum]] [[File:Prirodoslovni muzej u hrvatskom glavnom gradu Zagrebu.JPG|thumb|mini|Permanent exhibition]] Exhibitions at the Croatian Natural History Museum have included "[[Dormice]]: in Biology and the Kitchen"<ref name="informatica museologica" /> and "Lion's Pit", exhibiting the remains of a cave lion (''[[Panthera leo spelaea]]''), found deep in [[Vrtare Male]], a [[pit cave]] near [[Dramalj]], Croatia. With a body length of {{convert|3.6|m}}, the lion was at the time of discovery claimed to be one of the biggest found in the world thus far.<ref name="tportal cave lion">{{cite web |title=Najveći spiljski lav izlazi pred javnost |url=http://www.tportal.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/75478/Najveci-spiljski-lav-izlazi-pred-javnost.html|website=Tportal.hr |accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="cave lion jutarnji">{{cite web|title=U Dramlju pronađen najveći špiljski lav |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/u-dramlju-pronaden-najveci-spiljski-lav/271094/ |website=[[Jutarnji list]] |language=hr |accessdate=8 August 2015 |date=4 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151122163511/http://www.jutarnji.hr/u-dramlju-pronaden-najveci-spiljski-lav/271094/ |archivedate=November 22, 2015 }}</ref> Another notable exhibition displayed the reconstruction of a ''[[Megalodon]]'', an extinct giant shark found in the plains of northern Croatia, where the [[Paratethys|Paratethys ocean]] once stood.<ref name="im megalodon">{{cite journal |last1=Brezinščak|first1=Renata |title=Izložba Morski psi – Megalodon, gospodar neogenskih mora |journal=Informatica Museologica |date=December 2008 |volume=38|issue=3–4 |pages=86–88 |url=http://hrcak.srce.hr/file/198644 |accessdate=10 August 2015 |trans-title=The exhibition Sharks – Megalodon, Lord of the Neogene Seas|publisher=Museum Documentation Centre |location=Zagreb |language=hr|issn=1849-4277}}</ref> The museum held the first [[moss animal]] exhibition in the world in 2006, entitled "Neptune's Lace".<ref name="jutarnji neptune">{{cite web |title=Neptunova čipka |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/neptunova-cipka/25498/|website=[[Jutarnji list]] |accessdate=14 August 2015 |language=hr |date=1 April 2006}}</ref> In 2009, visitors had the opportunity to view [[crocodile]] fossils from the island [[Pag (island)|Pag]],<ref name="jutarnji croc">{{cite web |last1=Vuleta|first1=Diana |title=Na Pagu su živjeli krokodili! |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/na-pagu-su-zivjeli-krokodili-/336280/|website=[[Jutarnji list]] |accessdate=14 August 2015 |language=hr |date=6 November 2009}}</ref> while eighty live snakes owned by the Slovenian breeder Aleš Mlinar were exhibited in 2013.<ref name="vecernji snakes">{{cite web |title=Kraljevska kobra i etiopska ljutica dopuzale na Gornji grad! |url=http://www.vecernji.hr/ritam-grada/kraljevska-kobra-i-etiopska-ljutica-dopuzale-na-gornji-grad-544287|publisher=[[Večernji list]] |accessdate=14 August 2015 |language=hr |date=25 April 2013}}</ref>
The museum takes part in the Croatian [[Museum Night (Croatia)|Museum Night]] (''Noć muzeja''), an annual event whereby the public is allowed free entrance to many museums in Croatia during one night in the year. In the 2014 event, the museum was visited by more than 11,000 people.<ref name="jutarnji museum night">{{cite web |title=NOVI REKORD U Noći muzeja više od 350.000 posjetitelja |url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/novi-rekord-u-noci-muzeja-vise-od-350-000-posjetitelja/1161224/ |website=[[Jutarnji list]] |language=hr |accessdate=6 August 2015 |date=3 February 2014}}</ref> {{clear}}
== References == {{reflist|28em}}
