Breaking News, World News & Multimedia |publisher=International Herald Tribune |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated5">{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/0,1518,463174,00.html |title=The World From Berlin: Good Riddance to Coal Mining |publisher=Spiegel Online |date=2007-01-30 |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref> This exit is later than the EU-mandated end by 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/germany-stays-firm-on-plan-to-scrap-coal-subsidies-in-2018/a-6243150|title=Germany stays firm on plan to scrap coal subsidies in 2018 |date=17 November 2010|publisher=Deutsche Welle|website=dw.com}}</ref> Solar and wind are major sources of energy and renewable energy generation, around 15% as of December 2013,<ref>{{cite web|author=www.kenovate.com |url=http://www.rncos.com/Blog/2009/02/Germany-targets-47-Renewable-Energy-Production-by-2020.html |title=Germany targets 47% Renewable Energy Production by 2020 |publisher=Rncos.com |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref> and growing. Coal is still the largest source of power in Germany.
In 2007, [[Chancellor of Germany|German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] and her party agreed to legislation to phase out Germany's hard coal mining sector. That does not mean that they support phasing out coal in general. There were plans to build about 25 new plants in the coming years. Most German coal power plants were built in the 1960s, and have a low energy efficiency. Public sentiment against coal power plants is growing and the construction or planning of some plants has been stopped.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="autogenerated2"/><ref name="autogenerated3"/><ref name="autogenerated4"/><ref name="autogenerated5"/> A number are under construction and still being built. No concrete plan is in place to reduce coal-fired electricity generation. As of October 2015, the remaining coal plants still under planning include: Niederaussem, Profen, and Stade. The coal plants currently under construction include: Mannheim, Hamm D, Datteln, and Willhelmshaven. Between 2012 and 2015, six new plants went online. All of these plants are 600–1800  [[Megawatt|MW]]<sub>e</sub>.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://energytransition.de/2015/10/the-demise-of-coal-in-germany-and-globally/|title=The demise of coal in Germany and globally|date=15 October 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2014, Germany's coal consumption dropped for the first time, having risen each year since the low during the 2009 recession.<ref name="bp-statistical-review-2015"> {{cite book | title = BP Statistical Review of World Energy 2015 | publisher = BP | location = London, UK | url = https://www.bp.com/content/dam/bp/pdf/energy-economics/statistical-review-2015/bp-statistical-review-of-world-energy-2015-full-report.pdf | access-date = 2016-10-07 }} </ref>
A 2014 study, found that coal is not making a comeback in Germany, as is sometimes claimed. Rather renewables have more than offset the nuclear facilities that have been shutdown as a result of Germany's [[Nuclear power phase-out#Germany|nuclear phase-out]] (''Atomausstieg''). Hard coal plants now face financial stringency as their operating hours are cut back by the market. But in contrast, [[lignite]]-fired generation is in a safe position until the {{nowrap|mid-2020s}} unless government policies change. To phase-out coal, Germany should seek to strength the emissions trading system ([[European Union Emission Trading Scheme|EU-ETS]]), consider a carbon tax, promote [[efficient energy use|energy efficiency]], and strengthen the use of natural gas as a bridge fuel.<ref name="jungjohann-and-morris-2014"> {{cite book | last1 = Jungjohann | first1 = Arne | last2 = Morris | first2 = Craig | title = The German coal conundrum | date = June 2014 | publisher = Heinrich Böll Stiftung | location = Washington, DC, US | url = http://www.indiaenvironmentportal.org.in/files/file/German_Coal_Conundrum.pdf | access-date = 2016-10-07 }} </ref>
In 2016, the German government and affected [[lignite]] power plant operators [[:de:Mitteldeutsche Braunkohlengesellschaft|Mibrag]], [[RWE]], and [[Vattenfall]] reached an understanding (''Verständigung'') on the transfer of lignite power plant units into security standby (''Überführung von Braunkohlekraftwerksblöcken in die Sicherheitsbereitschaft''). As a result, eight lignite-fired power plants are to be mothballed and later closed, with the first plant scheduled to cease operation in October 2016 and the last in October 2019. The affected operators will receive state compensation for foregone profits. The [[European Commission]] has declared government plans to use €1.6{{nbsp}}billion of public financing for this purpose to be in line with EU [[state aid]] rules.<ref name="german-energy-blog-2016"> {{cite web | title = EU Commission Approves State Aid for Closure of Lignite-Fired Power Plants | date = 31 May 2016 | website = German Energy Blog | url = http://www.germanenergyblog.de/?p=19921 | access-date = 2016-07-28 }}</ref>
A 2016 study, found that the phase-out of lignite in [[Lusatia]] (''Lausitz'') by 2030 can be financed by future owner [[Energetický a průmyslový holding|EPH]] in a manner that avoids taxpayer involvement. Instead, liabilities covering decommissioning and land rehabilitation could be paid by EPH directly into a foundation, perhaps run by the public company [[:de:Lausitzer und Mitteldeutsche Bergbau-Verwaltungsgesellschaft|LMBV]]. The study calculates the necessary provisions at €2.6{{nbsp}}billion.<ref name="ieefa-2016"> {{cite web | title = IEEFA Europe: Blueprint for a Lignite Phase-Out in Germany | work = Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis | date = 22 September 2016 | url = http://ieefa.org/ieefa-europe-blueprint-lignite-phase-germany/ | access-date = 2016-09-23 }} </ref><ref name="wynn-and-julve-2016"> {{cite book | first1 = Gerard | last1 = Wynn | first2 = Javier | last2 = Julve | title = A Foundation-Based Framework for Phasing Out German Lignite in Lausitz | date = September 2016 | publisher = Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA) | url = http://ieefa.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/A-Foundation-Based-Framework-for-Phasing-Out-German-Lignite-in-Lausitz_September2016.pdf | access-date = 2016-09-23 }} </ref>
In November 2016, the German utility [[Evonik Industries#Energy Business Area|STEAG]] announced it will be decommissioning five coal-fired generating units in [[North Rhine-Westphalia]] and [[Saarland]] due to low wholesale electricity prices.<ref name="clew-2016a"> {{cite news | title = Utility to shut down five coal plants | date = 3 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/german-energy-use-stable-energiewendes-sobering-results/utility-shut-down-five-coal-plants | access-date = 2016-11-03 }} </ref><ref name="handelsblatt-2016"> {{cite news | title = Steag: Energiekonzern schaltet fünf Kohlekraftwerke ab | trans-title = Steag: Energy corporation switches off five coal-fired power plants | language = German | date = 2 November 2016 | newspaper = Handelsblatt | location = Düsseldorf, Germany | url = https://www.handelsblatt.com/unternehmen/industrie/steag-energiekonzern-schaltet-fuenf-kohlekraftwerke-ab/14784534.html | access-date = 2016-11-03 }} </ref>
A coal phase-out for Germany is implied in Germany's [[German Climate Action Plan 2050|Climate Action Plan 2050]], environment minister [[Barbara Hendricks (politician)|Barbara Hendricks]] said in an interview on 21{{nbsp}}November 2016. "If you read the Climate Action Plan carefully, you will find that the exit from coal-fired power generation is the immanent consequence of the energy sector target.{{nbsp}}... By 2030{{nbsp}}... half of the coal-fired power production must have ended, compared to 2014", she said.<ref name="clew-2016b"> {{cite news | title = Coal exit is in the Climate Action Plan | date = 21 November 2016 | work = Clean Energy Wire (CLEW) | location = Berlin, Germany | url = https://www.cleanenergywire.org/news/climate-plan-implies-coal-exit-minister-merkel-seeks-4th-term/coal-exit-climate-action-plan | access-date = 2016-11-22 }} </ref><ref name="goetze-and-schwarz-2016"> {{cite news | first1 = Susanne | last1 = Götze | first2 = Susanne | last2 = Schwarz | title = Kohleausstieg steht im Klimaschutzplan | trans-title = Coal exit is in the Climate Action Plan | language = German | date = 21 November 2016 | work = klimaretter.info | location = Berlin, Germany | url = http://www.klimaretter.info/politik/hintergrund/22297-hendricks-kohleausstieg-steht-im-klimaschutzplan | access-date = 2016-11-22 }} </ref>
Plans to cut down the ancient [[Hambach Forest]] to extend the [[Hambach open pit mine]] in 2018 have resulted in massive protests. On 5 Oct, 2018 a German court ruled against the further destruction of the forest for mining purposes. The ruling states, the court needs more time to reconsider the complaint. Angela Merkel, the chancellor of Germany, welcomed the court's ruling. The forest is located approximately 29 km km west of the city center of Cologne (specifically Cologne Cathedral).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/10/05/europe/germany-hambach-forest-court-intl/index.html|title=Hambach Forest clearance halted by German court|last=CNN|first=Laura Smith-Spark,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-11-16}}</ref>
==== Netherlands ==== On 22 September 2016, the Dutch parliament voted for a 55% cut in {{CO2}} emissions by 2030, a move which would require the closure of the country's five coal-fired power plants. The vote is not binding on the government however.<ref name="neslen=2016"> {{cite news | first = Arthur | last = Neslen | title = Dutch parliament votes to close down country's coal industry | date = 23 September 2016 | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London, UK | url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/sep/23/dutch-parliament-votes-to-close-down-countrys-coal-industry | access-date = 2016-09-23 }} </ref>
==== Spain ==== In October 2018, the [[Sánchez government]] and Spanish [[Labour union]]s settled an agreement to close ten [[Coal mining#SPain|Spanish coal mines]] at the end of 2018. The government pre-engaged to spend 250 million Euro to pay for early retirements, occupational retraining and structural change. In 2018, about 2.3 per cent of the electric energy produced in Spain was produced in [[coal-burning power plant]]s.<ref>theguardian.com 26. October 2018: [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/oct/26/spain-to-close-most-coal-mines-after-striking-250m-deal ''Spain to close most coal mines after striking €250m deal'']</ref>
=== Sweden === Sweden is constructing hydrogen-based pilot steel plant to replace coke and coal usage in steel production.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://energy.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/coal/sweden-starts-construction-on-fossil-fuel-free-steel-plant/64675998 |title=Sweden starts construction on fossil fuel-free steel plant |accessdate=21 June 2018 }}</ref> Once this technology is commercialized with the [[Hydrogen production|hydrogen generated]] from renewable energy sources ([[biogas]] or electricity), the carbon foot print of steel production would reduce drastically.<ref name=cf>{{cite web|url=http://www.solarpaces.org/new-iea-report/ |title=New IEA Report: Renewable Energy for Industry |accessdate=21 June 2018 }}</ref>
=== India === [[File:India Coal Production.png|thumb|Coal Production in [[India]], with a 1959-2020 axis (appears to end at 2012)]] India is the third largest consumer of coal in the world. India's federal energy minister is planning to stop importing thermal coal by 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/economy/thermal-coal-imports-must-be-stopped-goyal/article7209584.ece|title=Thermal coal imports will stop by 2017: Goyal|first=Our|last=Bureau|date=15 May 2015|publisher=}}</ref> The annual report of India's Power Ministry has a plan to grow power by about 80 GW as part of their 11th 5-year plan, and 79% of that growth will be in fossil fuel–fired power plants, primarily coal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://powermin.nic.in/indian_electricity_scenario/pdf/Annual_Report_2008-09_English.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718131617/http://powermin.nic.in/indian_electricity_scenario/pdf/Annual_Report_2008-09_English.pdf |archivedate=18 July 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> India plans four new "ultra mega" coal-fired power plants as part of that growth, each 4000 MW in capacity. {{As of|2015}}, there are six nuclear reactors under construction. In the first half of 2016, the amount of coal-fired generating capacity in pre-construction planning in India fell by 40,000 MW, according to results released by the Global Coal Plant Tracker.<ref>Alister Doyle, [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-coal-idUSKCN11C2N4 "Global coal power plans fall in 2016, led by China, India: study,"] Reuters, 6 September 2016</ref> In June 2016, India's Ministry of Power stated that no further power plants would be required in the next three years, and "any thermal power plant that has yet to begin construction should back off."<ref>[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/india-wont-need-extra-power-plants-for-next-three-years-says-government-report/articleshow/52545715.cms "India won't need extra power plants for next three years, says government report,"] The Economic Times, 2 June 2016</ref>
In cement production, carbon neutral biomass is being used to replace coal for reducing carbon foot print drastically.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zkg.de/en/artikel/zkg_Geocycle_secures_biomass_needs_from_local_farmers_in_India_3116884.html |title=Lafargeholcim - Geocycle secures biomass needs from local farmers in India |accessdate=21 June 2018 }}</ref><ref name=cf/>
=== New Zealand === In October 2007, the [[Helen Clark|Clark]] [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour]] government introduced a 10{{nbsp}}year moratorium on new fossil fuel thermal power generation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.powergenworldwide.com/index/display/articledisplay/308764/articles/power-engineering/industry-news/new-zealand-issues-ten-year-ban-on-new-thermal-power-plants.html |title=New Zealand issues ten-year ban on new thermal power plants |work=Power-Gen Worldwide |publisher=[[PennWell Corporation]] |date=2007-10-11 |accessdate=2011-01-07 }}</ref> The ban was limited to state-owned utilities, although an extension to the private sector was considered. The [[Fifth National Government of New Zealand|new government]] under MP [[John Key]] ([[New Zealand National Party|NZNP]]) [[New Zealand general election, 2008|elected in November 2008]] repealed this legislation.{{Citation needed|date=August 2015}}
In 2014, almost 80 per cent of the electricity produced in [[New Zealand]] was from [[sustainable energy]].<ref>{{cite news | website=www.sciencealert.com | date=10 August 2015 | url=http://www.sciencealert.com/new-zealand-will-shut-down-its-last-large-coal-fired-power-stations-in-2018 | title=New Zealand will shut down its last large coal-fired power generators in 2018 }}</ref> On 6 August 2015, [[Genesis Energy Limited]] announced that it would close its two last [[Fossil-fuel power station|coal-fired power stations]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.asx.com.au/asxpdf/20150806/pdf/430b9m38rq42jm.pdf | title=Market release: GNE announces timetable to end coal-fired generation in New Zealand}}</ref>
=== South Africa === As of 2007, South Africa's power sector is the 8th highest global emitter of CO<sub>2</sub>.<ref>https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2007/11/071114163448.htm</ref> In 2005/2006, 77% of South Africa's energy demand was directly met by coal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dme.gov.za/energy/coal.stm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091202053007/http://www.dme.gov.za/energy/coal.stm |archivedate=2 December 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> and when current projects come online, this ratio will increase in the near term.
There are no plans to phase out coal-fired power plants in South Africa, and indeed, the country is investing in building massive amounts of new coal-fired capacity to meet power demands, as well as modernizing the existing coal-fired plants to meet environmental requirements.
On April 6, 2010, the World Bank approved a $3.75B loan to South Africa to support the construction of the world's 4th largest coal-fired plant, at Medupi.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article7088297.ece | work=[[The Times]] | location=London | title=Britain may block World Bank loan for coal plant in South Africa | first=Ben | last=Webster | date=April 6, 2010 | accessdate=May 2, 2010}}</ref> The proposed World Bank loan includes a relatively small amount{{snd}} $260 million{{snd}} for wind and solar power.
Rated at 4800 GW, [[Medupi Power Station]] would join other mammoth coal-fired power plants already in operation in the country, namely [[Kendal Power Station]] (4100 GW), [[Majuba Power Station]] (4100 GW), and [[Matimba Power Station]] (4000 GW), as well as a similar-capacity [[Kusile Power Station]], at 4800 GW, currently under construction. Kusile is expected to come online in stages, starting in 2012, while Medupi is expected to first come online in 2013, with full capacity available by 2017. These schedules are provisional, and may change.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}}
Since 2008, South Africa's government started funding [[solar water heating]] installations. As of January 2016, there have been 400 000 domestic installations in total, with free-of-charge installation of low-pressure solar water heaters for low-cost homes or low-income households which have access to the electricity grid, while other installations are subsidised.<ref>http://www.ee.co.za/article/solar-water-heater-rollout-programme-gains-momentum.html</ref>
=== United Kingdom === [[Ed Miliband]] ([[Secretary of State for Energy and Climate Change|energy secretary]] from 3 October 2008{{snd}} 11 May 2010) announced that no new coal-fired power stations will be built in Britain from 2009 onwards unless they capture and bury at least 25% of greenhouse gases immediately and 100% by 2025 although at the time this was a statement of intent rather than something he was able to enforce.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2009/apr/23/clean-coal-energy-policy | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=John | last=Vidal | title=Clean coal push marks reversal of UK energy policy | date=April 23, 2009}}</ref>
[[Chris Huhne]] (energy secretary from 12 May 2010{{snd}} 5 February 2012) has confirmed that the legislation required to allow his office to enforce [[Emission standard#UK|emissions standards]] are proceeding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessgreen.com/bg/news/1806551/huhne-promises-coal-plants-ccs |title=Huhne promises no more coal plants without CCS |publisher=BusinessGreen |date=17 Aug 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref>
The UK is also subject to the EU's [[Large Combustion Plant Directive]] covering non-CO2 emissions which is expected to bring many older plants to a close over the next few years as they are too expensive to upgrade.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/quality/industrial/eu-international/lcpd/ |title=Large Combustion Plant Directive « Industrial emissions |publisher=Defra.gov.uk |accessdate=2013-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424052427/http://www.defra.gov.uk/environment/quality/industrial/eu-international/lcpd/ |archivedate=24 April 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
[[Amber Rudd]] (energy secretary from 11 May 2015) announced on 18 November 2015 that all coal-fired power stations would close by 2025. This will not be a complete phase out of fossil fuels because gas-fired power stations will continue to provide some [[firm power]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/energy/12001752/UK-coal-plants-must-close-by-2025-Amber-Rudd-to-announce.html|title=UK coal plants must close by 2025, Amber Rudd announces|publisher=}}</ref>
The closure of the last coal power station in March 2016 ended coal-fired [[Energy policy of Scotland|power production in Scotland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-35882883|title=Longannet switch-off ends coal-fired power production in Scotland|date=24 March 2016|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
=== United States === In 2017, fossil fuels provided 81 percent of the energy consumed in the United States, down from 86 percent in 2000.<ref>US Energy Information Administration, [https://www.eia.gov/totalenergy/data/monthly/pdf/sec1_7.pdf Primary energy consumption by source], accessed 5 Apr. 2018</ref>
{{US electricity generation by coal table}} [[File:Estimated Effect of Carbon Tax in US.png|left|thumb|Estimated effect of a [[carbon tax]] on sources of United States electrical generation (US Energy Information Administration)]] [[File:US Total Energy 1949-2011.png|thumb|Total energy consumption in the US by source: comparing fossil fuels with nuclear and renewable energy]] [[File:US Electricity Fossil Fuels vs Others.png|thumb|US electrical generation: fossil fuels vs. nuclear and renewable energy]]
In 2007, 154 new coal-fired plants were on the drawing board in 42 states.<ref>[https://www.wired.com/techbiz/media/news/2006/10/71952 Eco Concern: Coal Plant Boom] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214223405/http://www.wired.com/techbiz/media/news/2006/10/71952 |date=14 December 2010 }}</ref> By 2012, that had dropped to 15, mostly due to new rules limiting mercury emissions, and limiting carbon emissions to 1,000 pounds of CO<sub>2</sub> per megawatt-hour of electricity produced.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303404704577307524051798192|title=EPA Proposes CO|author=Keith Johnson in Washington, Rebecca Smith in San Francisco and Kris Maher in Pittsburgh|date=28 March 2012|work=WSJ}}</ref>
In July 2013, US Secretary of Energy [[Ernest Moniz]] outlined Obama administration policy on fossil fuels:
{{Block quote|In the last four years, we’ve more than doubled renewable energy generation from wind and solar power. However, coal and other fossil fuels still provide 80 percent of our energy, 70 percent of our electricity, and will be a major part of our energy future for decades. That’s why any serious effort to protect our kids from the worst effects of climate change must also include developing, demonstrating and deploying the technologies to use our abundant fossil fuel resources as cleanly as possible.<ref>Ernest Moritz, [http://energy.gov/articles/excerpts-energy-secretary-ernest-moniz-s-remarks-national-energy-technology-laboratory Excerpts of Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz’s Remarks at National Energy Technology Laboratory in Morgantown], [[United States Department of Energy]], 29 July 2013.</ref>}}
Then-US Energy Secretary [[Steven Chu]] and researchers for the US [[National Renewable Energy Laboratory]] have noted that greater electrical generation by non-[[Dispatchable generation|dispatchable]] renewables, such as wind and solar, will also increase the need for flexible natural gas-powered generators, to supply electricity during those times when solar and wind power are unavailable.<ref>April Lee and others, [http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy13osti/56324.pdf Opportunities for synergy between natural gas and renewable energy], National Renewable Energy Laboratory, Dec. 2012.</ref><ref>John Funk, [http://www.cleveland.com/business/index.ssf/2012/01/doe_boss_says_shale_gas_could.html DOE boss says shale gas could benefit wind and solar], Cleveland Plain Dealer, 18 Jan. 2012.</ref> Gas-powered generators have the ability to ramp up and down quickly to meet changing loads.<ref>US EIA, [http://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.cfm?id=13191 Natural gas-fired combustion turbines are generally used to meet peak electricity load], 1 Oct. 2013.</ref>
In the US, many of the fossil fuel phase-out initiatives have taken place at the state or local levels.
[[File:California Electricity Sources 2010.png|thumb|left|California electricity generation by source, 2010 (data from US EIA)]] [[File:Maine Electricity Source.png|thumb|left|Sources of electricity generated in Maine. 2010 (US EIA)]] [[File:Texas Electricity Source.png|thumb|left|Sources of electricity generated in Texas, 2010 (US EIA)]] [[File:Washington state Electricity Source.png|thumb|left|Sources of electricity generation in Washington state, 2010 (US EIA)]]
==== California ==== [[California]]'s SB 1368 created the first governmental moratorium on new coal plants in the United States. The law was signed in September 2006 by [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.energy.ca.gov/emission_standards/index.html |title=SB 1368 Emission Performance Standards |publisher=Energy.ca.gov |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref> took effect for investor-owned utilities in January 2007, and took effect for publicly owned utilities in August 2007. SB 1368 applied to long-term investments (five years or more) by California utilities, whether in-state or out-of-state. It set the standard for greenhouse gas emissions at 1,100 pounds of carbon dioxide per megawatt-hour, equal to the emissions of a combined-cycle natural gas plant. This standard created a de facto moratorium on new coal, since it could not be met without carbon capture and sequestration.<ref>[http://www.solutionsforglobalwarming.org/docs/SB1368_FS_FINAL.pdf "California Takes on Power Plant Emissions: SB 1368 Sets Groundbreaking Greenhouse Gas Performance Standard,"] [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] Fact Sheet, August 2007.</ref>
==== Maine ==== On April 15, 2008, [[Maine]] Governor [[John E. Baldacci]] signed LD 2126, "An Act To Minimize Carbon Dioxide Emissions from New Coal-Powered Industrial and Electrical Generating Facilities in the State." The law, which was sponsored by Rep. W. Bruce MacDonald (D-[[Boothbay, Maine|Boothbay]]), requires the Board of Environmental Protection to develop greenhouse gas emission standards for coal gasification facilities. It also puts a moratorium in place on building any new coal gasification facilities until the standards are developed.<ref>Rhonda Erskine, [http://www.wcsh6.com/news/article.aspx?storyid=84867 "Maine Governor Baldacci Signs Bill to Reduce Carbon Dioxide Emissions,"] [[WCSH]] [[WCSH6]].com, April 15, 2008</ref>
==== Oregon ==== In early March 2016, Oregon lawmakers approved a plan to stop paying for out-of-state coal plants by 2030 and require a 50 percent renewable energy standard by 2040.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/oregon-lawmakers-approve-far-reaching-climate-change-bill/ar-BBqiuvg?ocid=ansmsnnews11|title=Oregon lawmakers approve far-reaching climate change bill|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305215204/http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/oregon-lawmakers-approve-far-reaching-climate-change-bill/ar-BBqiuvg?ocid=ansmsnnews11|archivedate=5 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Environmental groups such as the [[American Wind Energy Association]] and leading Democrats praised the bill.
==== Texas ==== In 2006 a coalition of [[Texas]] groups organized a campaign in favor of a statewide moratorium on new coal-fired power plants. The campaign culminated in a "Stop the Coal Rush" mobilization, including rallying and lobbying, at the state capital in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] on February 11 and 12th, 2007.<ref>[http://texas.sierraclub.org/press/newsreleases/20070125.asp "Stop the Coal Rush" Rally & Lobby Day Set for February 11 & 12"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030034206/http://texas.sierraclub.org/press/newsreleases/20070125.asp |date=30 October 2008 }}, [[Sierra Club]] Lone Star Chapter.</ref> Over 40 citizen groups supported the mobilization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stopthecoalrush.com/participating-organizations/ |title=StopTheCoalRush - Hot Rush in Marketing |work=stopthecoalrush.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513110722/http://www.stopthecoalrush.com/participating-organizations/ |archivedate=13 May 2008 |df=dmy }}]</ref>
In January, 2007, A resolution calling for a 180-day moratorium on new pulverized coal plants was filed in the Texas Legislature by State Rep. [[Charles "Doc" Anderson]] (R-Waco) as House Concurrent Resolution 43.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legis.state.tx.us/tlodocs/80R/billtext/pdf/HC00043I.pdf|title=Text of HCR 43|publisher=}}</ref> The resolution was left pending in committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legis.state.tx.us/BillLookup/History.aspx?LegSess=80R&Bill=HCR43|title=Texas Legislature Online - 80(R) History for HCR 43|work=state.tx.us}}</ref> On December 4, 2007, Rep. Anderson announced his support for two proposed [[integrated gasification combined cycle]] (IGCC) coal plants proposed by [[Luminant]] (formerly TXU).<ref>[http://www.docandersonfortexas.com/news.htm Rep. Anderson press release] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828213707/http://www.docandersonfortexas.com/news.htm |date=28 August 2008 }}, December 4, 2007.</ref>
==== Washington state ==== [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] has followed the same approach as California, prohibiting coal plants whose emissions would exceed those of natural gas plants. Substitute Senate Bill 6001 (SSB 6001), signed on May 3, 2007, by Governor [[Christine Gregoire]], enacted the standard.<ref name="whitmanpioneer.com">Christina Russell, [http://whitmanpioneer.com/outdoors/2007/11/15/wallula-coal-plant-proposal-controversial-among-students-faculty/ "Wallula Coal Plant Proposal Controversial Among Students, Faculty,"] [[Whitman College]] Pioneer, 11/15/07</ref> As a result of SSB 6001, the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090716184525/http://www.energy-northwest.com/generation/igcc/index.php Pacific Mountain Energy Center] in Kalama was rejected by the state. However, a new plant proposal, the [http://www.wallulaenergy.com/ Wallula Energy Resource Center], shows the limits of the "natural gas equivalency" approach as a means of prohibiting new coal plants. The proposed plant would meet the standard set by SSB 6001 by capturing and sequestering a portion (65 percent, according to a plant spokesman) of its carbon.<ref name="whitmanpioneer.com"/>
==== Utility action in the US ==== * [[Progress Energy Carolinas]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://customerservicenumbers.com/co-progress-energy-carolinas |title=Progress Energy Carolinas Customer Service Phone Number, Reviews |publisher=Customerservicenumbers.com |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref> announced on June 1, 2007, that it was beginning a two-year moratorium on proposals for new coal-fired power plants while it undertook more aggressive efficiency and conservation programs. The company added, "Additional reductions in future electricity demand growth through energy efficiency could push the need for new power plants farther into the future."<ref>[http://www.progress-energy.com/aboutus/news/article.asp?id=16202 "Progress Energy Carolinas sets goal of doubling efficiency savings to 2,000 MW,"] [[Progress Energy Inc]] press release, June 1, 2007.</ref> * [[Public Service of Colorado]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rmao.com/documents/psco_rmao_oasis.html |title=Public Service Company of Colorado |publisher=Rmao.com |accessdate=2013-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130729232842/http://www.rmao.com/documents/psco_rmao_oasis.html |archivedate=29 July 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> concluded in its November 2007 Resource Plan: "In sum, in light of the now likely regulation of CO<sub>2</sub> emissions in the future due to broader interest in climate change issues, the increased costs of constructing new coal facilities, and the increased risk of timely permitting to meet planned in-service dates, Public Service does not believe it would not be prudent to consider at this time any proposals for new coal plants that do not include CO<sub>2</sub> capture and sequestration.<ref name="burned">[http://www.iccr.org/news/press_releases/pdf%20files/DontGetBurned08.pdf "Don't Get Burned: The Risks of Investing in New Coal-Fired Generating Facilities,"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030225727/http://www.iccr.org/news/press_releases/pdf%20files/DontGetBurned08.pdf |date=30 October 2008 }} Synapse Energy Economics, 2008, p. 11 (PDF file)</ref> * [[Xcel Energy]] noted in its 2007 Resource Plan that "given the likelihood of future carbon regulation, we have only modeled a future coal-based resource option that includes carbon capture and storage."<ref name="burned"/> * [[Minnesota Power Company]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mnpower.com/ |title=Minnesota Power, an ALLETE Company - Home |publisher=Mnpower.com |accessdate=2013-12-27}}</ref> announced in December 2007 that it would not consider a new coal resource without a carbon solution.<ref name="burned"/> * [[Avista Utilities]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avistautilities.com/|title=Welcome to Avista|work=avistautilities.com}}</ref> announced that it does not anticipate pursuing coal-fired power plants in the foreseeable future.<ref name="burned"/> * [[NorthWestern Energy]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northwesternenergy.com/|title=Home|work=northwesternenergy.com}}</ref> announced on December 17, 2007, that it planned to double its wind power capacity over the next seven years and steer away from new baseload coal plants. The plans are detailed in the company's 2007 Montana Electric Supply Resource Plan.<ref>[http://www.rnp.org/News/news_NWEnergy2007IRP17Dec07.html "NorthWestern Energy Plans For More Wind; Says New Coal is Too Risky,"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080723130232/http://www.rnp.org/News/news_NWEnergy2007IRP17Dec07.html |date=23 July 2008 }} Renewable Northwest Project, 12/17/07.</ref> * [[California Energy Commission]] (CEC) has initiated its review of two 53.4-megawatt solar thermal power plants that will each include a 40-megawatt biomass power plant to supplement the solar power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/news/news_detail.cfm/news_id=12363|title=EERE News: Georgia Power Wins Approval to Switch Coal Plant to Biomass Power|work=energy.gov}}</ref>
=== Japan === Japan, the world's third-largest economy, made a major move to use more fossil fuels in 2012, when the nation shut down nuclear reactors following the Fukishima accident. Nuclear, which had supplied 30 percent of Japanese electricity from 1987 to 2011, supplied only 2 percent in 2012 (hydropower supplied 8 percent). Nuclear electricity was replaced with electricity from petroleum, coal, and liquified natural gas. As a result, electricity generation from fossil fuels rose to 90 percent in 2012.<ref>[https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=10391 "Japan’s fossil-fueled generation remains high because of continuing nuclear plant outages"], US Energy Information Administration, 15 March 2013.</ref>
In January 2017, the Japanese government announced plans to build 45 new coal-fired power plants in the next ten years, largely to replace expensive electricity from petroleum power plants.<ref>Babs McHugh, [http://www.platts.com/latest-news/coal/sydney/japan-plans-to-build-45-new-coal-power-plants-27762428 "Japan plans to build 45 coal power plants in next decade,"] Platts, 3 Feb. 2017.</ref>
== Public opinion == {{Reduced pull quote|1=right |2=Those corporations that continue to invest in new fossil fuel exploration, new fossil fuel exploitation, are really in flagrant breach of their fiduciary duty because the science is abundantly clear that this is something we can no longer do. |3=[[Christiana Figueres]]|4=executive secretary of the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]]<ref>Cited in [[Tim Flannery]], ''Atmosphere of Hope. Solutions to the Climate Crisis'', [[Penguin Books]], 2015, pages 123-124 ({{ISBN|9780141981048}}).</ref>}}
=== Opinion polls ===
==== Opinion research ==== In October 2007, [http://www.civilsocietyinstitute.org/ Civil Society Institute] released the results of a poll of 1,003 US citizens conducted by Opinion Research Corporation.
The authors of the poll reported: "75 percent of Americans—including 65 percent of Republicans, 83 percent of Democrats and 76 percent of Independents—would 'support a five-year moratorium on new coal-fired power plants in the United States if there was stepped-up investment in clean, safe renewable energy—such as wind and solar—and improved home energy-efficiency standards.' Women (80 percent) were more likely than men (70 percent) to support this idea. Support also was higher among college graduates (78 percent) than among those who did not graduate from high school (68 percent)."<ref>Opinion Research Corporation, [http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/101807_CLEAN_survey_report.pdf A Post Fossil-Fuel America] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201122738/http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/101807_CLEAN_survey_report.pdf |date=1 December 2008 }}, Executive Summary, National Opinion Survey Produced for Citizens Lead for Energy Action Now (CLEAN), A Project of the Civil Society Institute, 18 October 2007</ref>
The exact question posed by the survey was as follows: "More than half of power plant-generated electricity comes from coal. Experts say that power plants are responsible for about 40 percent of U.S. carbon dioxide pollution linked to global warming. There are plans to build more than 150 new coal-fired power plants over the next several years. Would you support a five-year moratorium on new coal-fired power plants in the United States if there was stepped-up investment in clean, safe and renewable energy—such as wind and solar—and improved home energy-efficiency standards? Would you say definitely yes, probably yes, probably no, definitely no, or don't know."
The results were as follows:<ref>Opinion Research Corporation, [http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/101807_CLEAN_survey_report.pdf A Post Fossil-Fuel America] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201122738/http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/101807_CLEAN_survey_report.pdf |date=1 December 2008 }}, National Opinion Survey Produced for Citizens Lead for Energy Action Now (CLEAN), A Project of the Civil Society Institute, page 18, October 18, 2007</ref>
* 30% "definitely yes" * 45% "probably yes" * 13% "probably no" * 8% "definitely no" * 4% "don't know"
==== Gallup ==== In 2013, the Gallup organization determined that 41% of Americans wanted less emphasis placed on coal energy, versus 31% who wanted more. Large majorities wanted more emphasis placed on solar (76%), wind (71%), and natural gas (65%).<ref>Gallup, [http://www.gallup.com/poll/161519/americans-emphasis-solar-wind-natural-gas.aspx Americans want more emphasis on solar, wind, natural gas], 27 Mar. 2013.</ref>
==== ABC News/Washington Post ==== A 2009 ABC/Washington Post poll found 52% of Americans favored more coal mining (33% strongly favored), while 45% opposed (27% strongly opposed). The most support was for wind and solar, which were favored by 91% (79% strongly favored).<ref>ABC News/Washington Post, [http://abcnews.go.com/images/PollingUnit/1093a4Energy.pdf Energy policy has initial support], 28 August 2009.</ref>
=== CLEAN call to action === In October 2007, fifteen groups led by [http://theclean.org/ Citizens Lead for Energy Action Now] (CLEAN) called for a five-year moratorium on new coal-fired power plants, with no exception for plants sequestering carbon. The groups included Save Our Cumberland Mountains (Tennessee); Ohio Valley Environmental Council (West Virginia); Cook Inlet Keeper (Alaska); Christians for the Mountains (West Virginia); Coal River Mountain Watch (West Virginia); Kentuckians for the Commonwealth (Kentucky); Civil Society Institute (Massachusetts); Clean Power Now (Massachusetts); Indigenous Environmental Network (Minnesota); Castle Mountain Coalition (Alaska); Citizens Action Coalition (Indiana); Appalachian Center for the Economy & the Environment (West Virginia); Appalachian Voices (NC); and Rhode Island Wind Alliance (Rhode Island).<ref>[http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/101807release.cfm CLEAN press release] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509155325/http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/101807release.cfm |date=9 May 2008 }}, 18 October 2007.</ref>
=== Environmental Defense Fund === The US-based [[Environmental Defense Fund]] (EDF) has taken a stand in favor of natural gas production and [[hydraulic fracturing]], while pressing for stricter environmental controls on gas drilling, as a feasible way to replace coal.<ref>EDF, [http://www.edf.org/energy/natural-gas-policy Natural gas policy], accessed 4 Oct. 2013.</ref> The organization has funded studies jointly with the petroleum industry on the environmental effects of natural gas production. The organization sees natural gas as a way to quickly replace coal, and that natural gas in time will be replaced by renewable energy.<ref>EDF, [http://www.edf.org/climate/why-natural-gas-important Why natural gas is important], accessed 4 Oct. 2013.</ref> The policy has been criticized by some environmentalists.<ref>Larry Bernstein, [https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-05-22/national/39441658_1_oil-companies-energy-companies-kennedy-jr Environmental Defense Fund scolded by other green organizations on ‘fracking’] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109052409/http://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-05-22/national/39441658_1_oil-companies-energy-companies-kennedy-jr |date=9 November 2013 }}, Washington Post, 22 May 2013.</ref> EDF counsel and blogger Mark Brownstein answered:
{{quote|Demand for natural gas is not going away, and neither is hydraulic fracturing. We must be clear-eyed about this, and fight to protect public health and the environment from unacceptable impacts. We must also work hard to put policies in place that ensure that natural gas serves as an enabler of renewable power generation, not an impediment to it. We fear that those who oppose all natural gas production everywhere are, in effect, making it harder for the U.S. economy to wean itself from dirty coal.|Mark Brownstein, EDF council<ref>Mark Brownstein, [http://blogs.edf.org/energyexchange/2012/09/10/why-edf-is-working-on-natural-gas/ Why EDF is working on natural gas], 10 Sept. 2012</ref>}}
=== Other groups supporting a coal moratorium ===<!-- PLEASE RESPECT ALPHABETICAL ORDER --> * [[1Sky]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.1sky.org/about/1sky-solutions/no-new-coal|title=Solutions: Get Off Coal; Invest in Renewable Energy|work=1sky.org}}</ref> * [[Co-op America]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coopamerica.org/programs/climate/dirtyenergy/coal/index.cfm|title=Green America Climate Action: Dirty Energy: Coal is Bad|website=www.coopamerica.org}}</ref> * [[Energy Action Coalition]] * [[List of anti-nuclear groups in the United States#Sierra Club|Kansas Sierra Club]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kansas.sierraclub.org/Wind/Coal%20Moratorium.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030050120/http://kansas.sierraclub.org/Wind/Coal%20Moratorium.htm |archivedate=30 October 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> * [[Environmental groups and resources serving K–12 schools#Energy Action Coalition|Lead for Energy Action Now (CLEAN)]]<ref>[http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/callaction.cfm Citizens] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820161141/http://www.cleanenergyaction.net/callaction.cfm |date=20 August 2008 }}</ref> * [[Rainforest Action Network]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ran.org/what_we_do/global_finance/spotlight/coal_is_over/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080124054605/http://ran.org/what_we_do/global_finance/spotlight/coal_is_over/ |archivedate=24 January 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> * [[Rising Tide North America|Rising Tide]] Australia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.risingtide.org.au/cleancoal |title=Rising Tide - Your Eyes on Climate Change |work=risingtide.org.au |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160517051339/http://www.risingtide.org.au/cleancoal |archivedate=17 May 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref> * [[Sierra Club]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sierraclub.org/|title=Sierra Club Home Page: Explore, Enjoy, and Protect the Planet|work=Sierra Club}}</ref> * [[SixDegrees.org]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sixdegrees.org.au|title=Six Degrees - Coal and Climate Change|work=sixdegrees.org.au}}</ref> * [[Step It Up 2007#Step It Up|Step It Up 2007]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://stepitup2007.org/article.php?id=469 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011124939/http://stepitup2007.org/article.php?id=469 |archivedate=11 October 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
=== Shareholder resolutions in favor of a coal moratorium === * [http://www.trilliuminvest.com/ Trillium Asset Management], a social investment management company, submitted the resolution [http://trilliuminvest.com/resolutions/moritorium-on-coal-financing/ "Moratorium on Coal Financing"] to Bank of America in the 2007–2008 shareholder resolution season. The resolution concluded:
<blockquote> RESOLVED: Shareholders request that BOA's board of directors amend its GHG emissions policies to observe a moratorium on all financing, investment and further involvement in activities that support MTR coal mining or the construction of new coal-burning power plants that emit carbon dioxide.<ref>[http://trilliuminvest.com/resolutions/moritorium-on-coal-financing/ "Moratorium on Coal Financing,"] accessed April 2008.</ref> </blockquote>
=== Prominent individuals supporting a coal moratorium === * US politician [[Albert Gore, Jr.|Al Gore]] stated:<ref name="nichols-2008"> {{cite news | first = Michelle | last = Nichols | title = Gore urges civil disobedience to stop coal plants | date = 24 September 2008 | work = Reuters | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-coal-goreenivro-idUSTRE48N7AA20080924 | access-date = 2016-09-22 }} </ref>
{{Block quote|If you're a young person looking at the future of this planet and looking at what is being done right now, and not done, I believe we have reached the stage where it is time for [[civil disobedience]] to prevent the construction of new coal plants that do not have carbon capture and sequestration.}}
* Banker and financier [[Tom Sanzillo]], currently First Deputy Comptroller for the state of New York, called for a moratorium on new coal plants in the state of Iowa. Citing slow growth in electricity demand and better alternative sources of energy, Sanzillo said, "It's not only good public policy, it's great economics."<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zG0pUjBr8KU|title=Economics of Coal in IA: Investor Sees Poor Future for Coal|date=22 January 2008|work=YouTube}}</ref>
=== Prominent individuals supporting a coal phase-out === * [[Eric Schmidt]], CEO of Google, called for replacing all [[fossil fuel]]s with renewable sources of energy in twenty years.<ref>[http://www.mercurynews.com/olympics/ci_10419245 "Google CEO ERic Schmidt offers energy plan,"] [[San Jose Mercury News]], 9/9/08</ref>
=== Mayors supporting a coal moratorium === On 13 October 2007, Pocatello, Idaho, mayor Roger Chase told other mayors from across the state attending an Association of Idaho Cities legislative committee that he favored a moratorium no new coal plants in the state.<ref>[http://www.localnews8.com/Global/story.asp?S=7211810 "E. Idaho Mayor Doesn't Want Coal-Fired Plant in State,"] [[Associated Press]], 10/14/07.</ref>
On 1 June 2007, Park City, Utah, mayor Dana Wilson wrote a letter to [[Warren Buffett]] expressing the city's opposition to three coal plants proposed by Rocky Mountain Power.<ref>[http://www.lesscoal.com/ParkCity%20Endorsement.htm Letter from Dana Wilson to Warren Buffett], 1 June 2007.</ref>
In November 2007, Salt Lake City mayor [[Rocky Anderson]] expressed his support for a coal moratorium at a rally organized by the Step It Up! campaign.<ref>[http://events.stepitup2007.org/november/reports/2097 "Event Report: Step It Up SLC,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100406073257/http://events.stepitup2007.org/november/reports/2097 |date=6 April 2010 }} 11/3/07.</ref>
In December 2007, Charlottesville, VA, mayor Dave Norris blogged in favor of a moratorium on new coal-fired power plants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cvilledave.blogspot.com/2007/12/clean-energy-for-cville-beyond.html |title=Clean Energy for Cville & Beyond |work= CvilleDave |author=Dave Norris |date=14 December 2007 |access-date= 21 September 2016}}</ref> On 19 December 2007, Charlottesville passed the Charlottesville Clean Energy Resolution putting the city on record as supporting a moratorium.<ref>{{cite web |title=Charlottesville Clean Energy Resolution |url=https://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php/Charlottesville_Clean_Energy_Resolution |website=SOURCEWATCH |publisher=The Center for Media and Democracy |accessdate=20 September 2018 |date=17 December 2007}}</ref>
=== Local governments supporting a coal moratorium === In January 2008, Black Hawk County (Iowa) Health Board recommended that the state adopt a moratorium on new coal-fired power plants until it enacts tougher air pollution standards.<ref>[http://www.wcfcourier.com/articles/2008/01/16/news/top_story/doc478e26fd33f2f364595766.txt "Board calls for coal plant moratorium,"] [[The Waterloo-Cedar Falls Courier]], 16 January 2008.</ref>
== Alternative Sources of Energy == {{See also|Alternative energy|energy transition|100% renewable energy}}
[[Alternative energy]] refers to any source of energy that can substitute the role of fossil fuels. [[Renewable energy]], or energy that is harnessed from [[Renewable resource|renewable sources]], is an alternative energy. However, alternative energy can refer to non renewable sources as well, like [[Nuclear power|nuclear energy]]. Between the alternative sources of energy are: [[solar energy]], [[hydroelectricity]], [[marine energy]], [[Wind power|wind energy]], [[geothermal energy]], [[biofuel]]s, [[ethanol]] and [[Hydrogen economy|Hydrogen]].
[[Efficient energy use|Energy efficiency]] is complementary to the use of alternative energy sources, when phasing-out fossil fuels.
=== Renewable energy === [[File:Bp world energy consumption 2016.gif|thumb|The worldwide growth of renewable energy is shown by the green line<ref>[http://www.bp.com/statisticalreview Statistical Review of World Energy], Workbook (xlsx), London, 2016</ref>]]
Renewable energy is [[energy]] that comes from resources which are naturally replenished such as [[sunlight]], [[wind]], [[rain]], [[tidal energy|tides]], [[wave power|waves]], and [[geothermal energy|geothermal heat]]. {{As of|2014}}, 19% of global final energy consumption comes from [[renewable resource]]s, with 9% of all energy from traditional [[biomass]], mainly used for [[heating]], 1% from biofuels, 4% from [[hydroelectricity]] and 4% from biomass, geothermal or solar heat. Popular renewables (wind, solar, geothermal and biomass for power) accounted for another 1.4% and are growing rapidly.<ref>http://www.ren21.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/REN21_GSR2016_KeyFindings_en_10.pdf pg18</ref> While renewable energy supplies are growing and have displaced coal in some regions, the amount of coal burned in 2021, is expected to be the same as it was in 2014.<ref>http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/MediumTermCoalMarketReport2016ExecutiveSummaryEnglishversion.pdf pg3</ref>
=== Hydroelectricity === [[File:Chief Joseph Dam.jpg|thumb|[[Chief Joseph Dam]] near [[Bridgeport, Washington]], US, is a major run-of-the-river station without a sizeable reservoir.]] In 2015, [[Hydroelectricity|hydroelectric energy]] generated 16.6% of the worlds total electricity and 70% of all renewable electricity.<ref>http://www.ren21.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/GSR_2016_Full_Report_REN21.pdf</ref> In Europe and North America environmental concerns around land flooded by large [[reservoir]]s ended 30 years of dam construction in the 1990s. Since then large dams and reservoirs continue to be built in countries like China, Brazil and India. [[Run-of-the-river hydroelectricity]] and [[small hydro]] have become popular alternatives to conventional dams that may create reservoirs in environmentally sensitive areas.
=== Wind power === {{Main|Wind farm}} [[File:Turbiny wiatrowe w Szwecji, 2011 ubt.JPG|thumb|[[Lillgrund Wind Farm]] in Sweden]] [[File:windpark Estinnes 20juli2010 kort voor voltooiing.jpg|thumb|First wind farm consisting of 7,5 MW Enercon E-126 turbines, [[Estinnes]], [[Belgium]], 20 July 2010, two months before completion; note the 2-part blades.]]
A wind farm is a group of [[wind turbine]]s in the same location used to produce electric power. A large wind farm may consist of several hundred individual wind turbines, and cover an extended area of hundreds of square miles, but the land between the turbines may be used for agricultural or other purposes. A wind farm may also be located offshore.
Wind power has grown dramatically since 2005 and by 2015 supplied almost 1% of global energy consumption.<ref>http://www.ren21.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/REN21_GSR2016_KeyFindings_en_10.pdf page 18</ref>
Many of the largest operational onshore wind farms are located in the United States and China. The [[Gansu Wind Farm]] in China has over 5,000 MW installed with a goal of 20,000 MW by 2020. China has several other "wind power bases" of similar size. The [[Alta Wind Energy Center]] in [[California]], United States is the largest onshore wind farm outside of China, with a capacity of 1020 MW of power.<ref name=terragen>[http://www.terra-genpower.com/News/Terra-Gen-Power-Announces-Closing-of-$650-Million-.aspx Terra-Gen Press Release] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150902091230/http://www.terra-genpower.com/News/Terra-Gen-Power-Announces-Closing-of-$650-Million-.aspx |date=2 September 2015 }}, 17 April 2012</ref> As of February 2012, the [[Walney Wind Farm]] in the United Kingdom is the largest offshore wind farm in the world at 367 MW, followed by [[Thanet Offshore Wind Project]] (300 MW), also in the United Kingdom. As of February 2012, the [[Fântânele-Cogealac Wind Farm]] in Romania is the largest onshore wind farm in [[Europe]] at 600 MW.<ref name=cez>{{cite web|url=http://www.cez.cz/en/cez-group/media/press-releases/4051.html|title=CEZ Group - The Largest Wind Farm in Europe Goes Into Trial Operation|author1=FG Forrest |author2=a. s. |author3=fg {zavináč } fg {tečka} cz - Content Management System - Edee CMS; SYMBIO Digital, s. r. o. - Webdesign|work=cez.cz}}</ref>
There are many large wind farms under construction and these include [[Sinus Holding Wind Farm]] (700 MW), [[Anholt Offshore Wind Farm]] (400 MW), [[BARD Offshore 1]] (400 MW), [[Clyde Wind Farm]] (350 MW), [[Greater Gabbard wind farm]] (500 MW), [[Lincs Wind Farm]] (270 MW), [[London Array]] (1000 MW), [[Lower Snake River Wind Project]] (343 MW), [[Macarthur Wind Farm]] (420 MW), [[Shepherds Flat Wind Farm]] (845 MW), and [[Sheringham Shoal Offshore Wind Farm|Sheringham Shoal]] (317 MW).
[[Wind power in Denmark]] produced the equivalent of 42.1% of total electricity consumption in 2015,<ref name=euractiv1>{{cite web|url=http://www.euractiv.com/sections/climate-environment/denmark-breaks-its-own-world-record-wind-energy-321002|title=Denmark breaks its own world record in wind energy|website=EURACTIV.com}}</ref><ref name=enet42>{{cite web|url=http://energinet.dk/EN/El/Nyheder/Sider/Dansk-vindstroem-slaar-igen-rekord-42-procent.aspx|title=New record-breaking year for Danish wind power|website=energinet.dk|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160125083857/http://energinet.dk/EN/El/Nyheder/Sider/Dansk-vindstroem-slaar-igen-rekord-42-procent.aspx|archivedate=25 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> however, use of wind for heating is minor.<ref name=wittboil>Wittrup, Sanne. "[http://ing.dk/artikel/dong-vores-kraftvaerker-bruger-allerede-billig-vindmoellestroem-i-elpatroner-173488 Dong: Vores kraftværker bruger allerede billig vindmøllestrøm i elpatroner]" ''[[Ingeniøren]]'', 15 January 2015. Retrieved: January 2015.</ref><ref>Blarke, Morten Boje. "[http://smartvarme.dk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3046&Itemid=80 Liste over el-drevne varmepumper i fjernvarmen]" ''SmartVarme.dk'', 12 February 2014. Retrieved: January 2015.</ref><ref>Capion, Karsten. "[http://www.danskenergi.dk/Analyse/Analyser/09_MulighederFjernvarmeDecentraleOmraader.aspx Analyse nr. 9 - Mulighederne for den fremtidige fjernvarmeproduktion i decentrale områder] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208211010/http://www.danskenergi.dk/Analyse/Analyser/09_MulighederFjernvarmeDecentraleOmraader.aspx |date=8 December 2015 }}" ''Danish Energy'', 15 January 2014. Retrieved: 15 January 2015.</ref><ref>Blarke, Morten Boje. "[http://www.fleksenergi.dk/Files/Billeder/FleksEnergi%20pr%C3%A6sentationer/blarke-17april-intro.pdf Store eldrevne varmepumper]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}" ''[[Aalborg University]]'', 17 April 2013. Retrieved: January 2015.</ref>
=== Solar === {{Main|Solar power}}{{Main|Solar energy}} In 2017, solar power provided 1.7% of total worldwide electricity production, growing at 35% per annum.<ref name=bp2018>[https://www.bp.com/en/global/corporate/energy-economics/statistical-review-of-world-energy/renewable-energy/solar-energy.html BP Global: Solar energy]</ref> By 2020 the solar contribution to global final energy consumption is expected to exceed 1%.<ref>http://www.ren21.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/REN12-GSR2015_Onlinebook_low_nolinks.pdf pg 27 & 28</ref>
==== Solar photovoltaics ==== [[File:LieberoseSolarpark.jpg|thumb|The 71.8 MW [[Lieberose Photovoltaic Park]] in Germany]] {{Main|Photovoltaics}}{{Main|List of photovoltaic power stations}} [[Solar photovoltaic cell]]s convert sunlight into electricity and many solar [[photovoltaic power station]]s have been built. The size of these stations has increased progressively over the last decade with frequent new capacity [[Photovoltaic power station#Noteworthy solar parks|records]].
As of January 2013, the largest individual photovoltaic (PV) power plants in the world are [[Agua Caliente Solar Project]], (Arizona, over 247 MW connected{{snd}} to increase to 397 MW), [[Golmud Solar Park]] (China, 200 MW), [[Mesquite Solar project]] (Arizona, 150 MW), [[Neuhardenberg Solar Park]] (Germany, 145 MW), [[Templin Solar Park]] (Germany, 128 MW), [[Toul-Rosières Solar Park]] (France, 115 MW), and [[Perovo Solar Park]] (Ukraine, 100 MW). The [[Charanka Solar Park]] is a collection of solar power stations of which 214 MW were reported complete in April 2012,<ref name="Charanka">{{cite news|title=Gujarat's 214 MW solar park named as Asia's largest single PV plant|url=http://www.pv-tech.org/news/gujarats_214mw_solar_park_named_as_asias_largest_single_pv_plant|access-date=2016-09-23|newspaper=PV Tech|date=23 April 2012}}</ref> on a 2000 [[hectare|ha]] site.<ref>{{cite web|title=Site plan of Charanka Solar Park, Gujarat, India|url=http://www.wiki-solar.org/map/sites/index.html?Charanka_Solar_Park?a?13?23.9?71.2|publisher=[[Wiki-Solar]]|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> It is part of [[Gujarat Solar Park]],<ref>[http://www.ahmedabadmirror.com/article/4/20120419201204191656225152164bad9/Asia%E2%80%99s-largest-solar-field-%E2%80%98Gujarat-Solar-Park%E2%80%99-switched-on-in-India.html Asia's largest solar field 'Gujarat Solar Park' switched on in India] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130612041950/http://www.ahmedabadmirror.com/article/4/20120419201204191656225152164bad9/Asia%E2%80%99s-largest-solar-field-%E2%80%98Gujarat-Solar-Park%E2%80%99-switched-on-in-India.html |date=12 June 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gujaratsolarpark.com/|title=Website|work=gujaratsolarpark.com}}</ref> a group of solar farms at various locations in the [[Gujarat]] state of India, with overall capacity of 702 MW.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sldcguj.com/Report/InstalledCapacity.asp|title=State Load Despatch Centre (SLDC)|work=sldcguj.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127100001/http://www.sldcguj.com/Report/InstalledCapacity.asp|archivedate=27 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> There are a total of 570 MW of solar parks in Golmud, with 500 MW more expected in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/usa/business/2012-03/02/content_14744509.htm|title=China|work=chinadaily.com.cn}}</ref>
Many large plants are under construction. The [[Desert Sunlight Solar Farm]] is a 550 MW [[solar power]] plant under construction in [[Riverside County, California]], that will use thin-film solar [[photovoltaic]] modules made by [[First Solar]].<ref name=rew11>{{cite web |url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2011/09/doe-closes-on-three-major-solar-projects |title=DOE Closes on Four Major Solar Projects |date= 30 September 2011 |work= Renewable Energy World }}</ref> The [[Topaz Solar Farm]] is a 550 MW photovoltaic power plant, being built in [[San Luis Obispo County, California]].<ref name=re11>{{cite web |url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2011/12/billionaire-buffett-bets-on-solar-energy |title=Billionaire Buffett Bets on Solar Energy |author=Steve Leone |date=7 December 2011 |work=Renewable Energy World }}</ref> The [[Blythe Solar Power Project]] is a 500 MW photovoltaic station under construction in [[Riverside County, California]]. The [[Agua Caliente Solar Project]] is a 290 megawatt photovoltaic solar generating facility being built in [[Yuma County, Arizona]]. The [[California Valley Solar Ranch]] (CVSR) is a 250 [[megawatt]] (MW) [[solar photovoltaic]] [[power plant]], which is being built by [[SunPower]] in the [[Carrizo Plain]], northeast of [[California Valley, California|California Valley]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/nrg-energy-completes-acquisition-of-250-megawatt-california-valley-solar-ranch-from-sunpower-2011-09-30 |title=NRG Energy Completes Acquisition of 250-Megawatt California Valley Solar Ranch from SunPower |date=30 September 2011 |work=MarketWatch }}</ref> The 230 MW [[Solar power plants in the Mojave Desert#Antelope Valley Solar Ranch|Antelope Valley Solar Ranch]] is a [[First Solar]] photovoltaic project which is under construction in the Antelope Valley area of the Western Mojave Desert, and due to be completed in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.solarserver.com/solar-magazine/solar-news/current/2011/kw40/exelon-purchases-230-mw-antelope-valley-solar-ranch-one-from-first-solar.html |title=Exelon purchases 230 MW Antelope Valley Solar Ranch One from First Solar |date=4 October 2011 |work=Solar Server |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118064557/http://www.solarserver.com/solar-magazine/solar-news/current/2011/kw40/exelon-purchases-230-mw-antelope-valley-solar-ranch-one-from-first-solar.html |archivedate=18 January 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Many of these plants are integrated with agriculture and some use innovative tracking systems that follow the sun's daily path across the sky to generate more electricity than conventional fixed-mounted systems. Solar power plants have no fuel costs or emissions during operation.
==== Concentrated solar power ==== [[File:12-05-08 AS1.JPG|thumb|The 150 MW [[Andasol solar power station]] is a commercial [[parabolic trough]] [[solar thermal]] power plant, located in [[Renewable energy in Spain|Spain]]. The Andasol plant uses tanks of molten salt to store solar energy so that it can continue generating electricity even when the sun isn't shining.<ref>{{cite web |url= |title=Saving for a rainy day |author=Edwin Cartlidge |date=18 November 2011 |work=Science (Vol 334) |pages=922–924 }}</ref>]]
{{See also|Concentrated solar power}} Concentrating Solar Power (CSP) systems use lenses or mirrors and tracking systems to focus a large area of sunlight into a small beam. The concentrated heat is then used as a heat source for a conventional power plant. A wide range of concentrating technologies exists; the most developed are the parabolic trough, the concentrating linear fresnel reflector, the Stirling dish and the solar power tower. Various techniques are used to track the Sun and focus light. In all of these systems a [[working fluid]] is heated by the concentrated sunlight, and is then used for power generation or energy storage.<ref name="Martin 2005">Martin and Goswami (2005), p. 45</ref>
=== Biofuels === {{Main|Biofuel}} [[Biofuels]], in the form of [[liquid fuels]] derived from plant materials, are entering the market. However, many of the biofuels that are currently being supplied have been criticised for their adverse impacts on the [[natural environment]], [[food security]], and [[land use]].<ref name=roy>[[The Royal Society]] (January 2008). ''Sustainable biofuels: prospects and challenges'', {{ISBN|978-0-85403-662-2}}, p. 61.</ref><ref name=sol>Gordon Quaiattini. [http://www.canada.com/components/print.aspx?id=e08c8e19-4a95-491c-9386-d30afeab5cdf&sponsor= Biofuels are part of the solution]{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''Canada.com'', 25 April 2008. Retrieved 23 December 2009.</ref>
=== Biomass === [[Biomass]] is [[biomaterial|biological material]] from living, or recently living organisms, most often referring to plants or plant-derived materials.<ref name="Biomass Energy Center">[http://www.biomassenergycentre.org.uk/portal/page?_pageid=76,15049&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL Biomass Energy Center] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061008081905/http://www.biomassenergycentre.org.uk/portal/page?_pageid=76,15049&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL |date=8 October 2006 }}. Biomassenergycentre.org.uk. Retrieved on 2012-02-28.</ref> As a [[renewable energy source]], biomass can either be used directly, or indirectly{{snd}} once or converted into another type of energy product such as [[biofuel]]. Biomass can be converted to energy in three ways: ''thermal conversion'', ''chemical conversion'', and ''biochemical conversion''.
Using biomass as a fuel produces [[air pollution]] in the form of [[carbon monoxide]], [[carbon dioxide]], [[NOx]] (nitrogen oxides), VOCs ([[volatile organic compound]]s), particulates and other pollutants at levels above those from traditional fuel sources such as [[coal]] or [[natural gas]] in some cases (such as with indoor heating and cooking).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://michiganmessenger.com/33868/proposed-biomass-plant-better-than-coal |title=Proposed biomass plant: Better than coal? |author=Eartha Jane Melzer |date=26 January 2010 |work=The Michigan Messenger |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120514091947/http://michiganmessenger.com/33868/proposed-biomass-plant-better-than-coal |archivedate=14 May 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhang | first1 = J. | last2 = Smith | first2 = K. R. | doi = 10.1289/ehp.9479 | title = Household Air Pollution from Coal and Biomass Fuels in China: Measurements, Health Impacts, and Interventions | journal = Environmental Health Perspectives | volume = 115 | issue = 6 | pages = 848–855 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17589590| pmc =1892127 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1007/BF01319012|journal=Archives of Virology|volume=130|title=Announcement|year=1993|pages=225}}</ref> Utilization of wood biomass as a fuel can also produce fewer particulate and other pollutants than open burning as seen in wildfires or direct heat applications.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.3155/1047-3289.61.1.63|journal=Journal of the Air & Waste Management Association|volume=61|issue=1|year=2011|pages=63–68|title=Emission Reductions from Woody Biomass Waste for Energy as an Alternative to Open Burning|last1=Springsteen|first1=Bruce|last2=Christofk|first2=Tom|last3=Eubanks|first3=Steve|last4=Mason|first4=Tad|last5=Clavin|first5=Chris|last6=Storey|first6=Brett}}</ref> [[Black carbon]]{{snd}} a pollutant created by combustion of fossil fuels, biofuels, and biomass{{snd}} is possibly the second largest contributor to global warming.<ref name="starke-2009"> {{cite book | last = Starke | first = Linda | title = State of the World 2009: Into a Warming World: a WorldWatch Institute Report on Progress Toward a Sustainable Society | date = 2009 | publisher = WW Norton and Company | isbn = 978-0-393-33418-0 }} </ref>{{rp|56–57}} In 2009 a Swedish study of the giant brown haze that periodically covers large areas in South Asia determined that it had been principally produced by biomass burning, and to a lesser extent by fossil fuel burning.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1126/science.1164857|title=Brown Clouds over South Asia: Biomass or Fossil Fuel Combustion?|year=2009|last1=Gustafsson|first1=O.|last2=Krusa|first2=M.|last3=Zencak|first3=Z.|last4=Sheesley|first4=R. J.|last5=Granat|first5=L.|last6=Engstrom|first6=E.|last7=Praveen|first7=P. S.|last8=Rao|first8=P. S. P.|last9=Leck|first9=C.|last10=Rodhe|first10=H.|journal=Science|volume=323|issue=5913|pages=495–8|pmid=19164746|display-authors=8|bibcode=2009Sci...323..495G}}</ref> [[Energy in Denmark|Denmark]] has increased the use of biomass and garbage,<ref>[http://www.danskfjernvarme.dk/nyheder/presseklip/151127klimaraad-affaldsimport-vil-belaste-dansk-co2regnskab Klimaråd: Affaldsimport vil belaste dansk CO2-regnskab] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151128144041/http://www.danskfjernvarme.dk/nyheder/presseklip/151127klimaraad-affaldsimport-vil-belaste-dansk-co2regnskab |date=28 November 2015 }} 27 November 2015.</ref> and decreased the use of coal.<ref>[http://www.ens.dk/sites/ens.dk/files/info/tal-kort/statistik-noegletal/aarlig-energistatistik/energistatistik_2014.pdf Danish energy statistics, 2014] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160121123923/http://www.ens.dk/sites/ens.dk/files/info/tal-kort/statistik-noegletal/aarlig-energistatistik/energistatistik_2014.pdf |date=21 January 2016 }} page 5 and 12</ref>
=== Nuclear energy === The 2014 [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] report identifies nuclear energy as one of the technologies that can provide electricity with less than 5% of the lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions of coal power.<ref>http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg3/ipcc_wg3_ar5_chapter7.pdf</ref> There are more than 60 nuclear reactors shown as under construction in the list of [[Nuclear power by country]] with China leading at 23. Globally, more nuclear power reactors have closed than opened in recent years but overall capacity has increased.<ref name="econ13">{{cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/babbage/2013/11/difference-engine-0|title=Difference Engine: The nuke that might have been|date=11 November 2013|author=|work=The Economist}}</ref> China has stated its plans to double nuclear generation by 2030. India also plans to greatly increase its nuclear power.
Several countries have enacted laws to cease construction on new nuclear power stations. Several European countries have debated [[Nuclear power phase-out|nuclear phase-outs]] and others have completely shut down some reactors. Three [[nuclear accidents]] have influenced the slowdown of nuclear power: the 1979 [[Three Mile Island accident]] in the United States, the 1986 [[Chernobyl disaster]] in the USSR, and the 2011 [[Fukushima nuclear disaster]] in Japan. Following the March 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster, Germany has permanently shut down eight of its 17 reactors and pledged to close the rest by the end of 2022.<ref name="Annika Breidthardt">{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/05/30/us-germany-nuclear-idUKTRE74Q2P120110530|title=German government wants nuclear exit by 2022 at latest|date=30 May 2011|work=Reuters|author=Annika Breidthardt}}</ref> Italy voted overwhelmingly to keep their country non-nuclear.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://referendum.interno.it/referendum/refe110612/RFT0003.htm|title=Italy Nuclear Referendum Results|date=13 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325171121/http://referendum.interno.it/referendum/refe110612/RFT0003.htm|archivedate=25 March 2012|df=dmy}}</ref> Switzerland and Spain have banned the construction of new reactors.<ref name="nweek11">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2011/11/27/post-fukushima-nuclear-power-changes-latitudes.html|title=Nuclear Power Goes Rogue|date=28 November 2011|author=[[Henry Sokolski]]|work=Newsweek}}</ref> Japan's prime minister has called for a dramatic reduction in Japan's reliance on nuclear power.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-28/nuclear-promotion-dropped-in-japan-energy-policy-after-fukushima.html|title=Nuclear Promotion Dropped in Japan Energy Policy After Fukushima|date=28 October 2011|lastauthoramp=yes|author1=Tsuyoshi Inajima|author2=Yuji Okada|work=Bloomberg}}</ref> Taiwan's president did the same. [[Shinzō Abe]], the new prime minister of Japan since December 2012, announced a plan to restart some of the 54 Japanese nuclear power plants and to continue some nuclear reactors under construction.
As of 2016, countries such as [[Anti-nuclear movement in Australia|Australia]], [[Anti-nuclear movement in Austria|Austria]], [[Nuclear energy in Denmark|Denmark]], [[Nuclear energy in Greece|Greece]], [[Nuclear energy in Malaysia|Malaysia]], [[New Zealand's nuclear-free zone|New Zealand]], and [[Nuclear energy in Norway|Norway]] have no nuclear power stations and remain opposed to nuclear power.<ref name="economist.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.economist.com/node/18441163|title=Nuclear power: When the steam clears|date=24 March 2011|page=|author=|work=The Economist}}</ref><ref name="gl2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.greenleft.org.au/node/47834|title=Germany: Nuclear power to be phased out by 2022|date=5 June 2011|author=Duroyan Fertl|work=Green Left}}</ref> [[Anti-nuclear movement in Germany|Germany]], [[Italy]], [[Anti-nuclear movement in Spain|Spain]] and [[Anti-nuclear movement in Switzerland|Switzerland]] are phasing-out their nuclear power.<ref name="econ13" /><ref name="gl2011" /><ref>Erika Simpson and [[Ian Fairlie]], [http://www.lfpress.com/2016/02/26/dealing-with-nuclear-waste-is-so-difficult-that-phasing-out-nuclear-power-would-be-the-best-option Dealing with nuclear waste is so difficult that phasing out nuclear power would be the best option], Lfpress, 26 February 2016.</ref><ref name="James Kanter">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/26/business/global/26nuclear.html?_r=1|title=Switzerland Decides on Nuclear Phase-Out|date=25 May 2011|page=|author=James Kanter|work=New York Times}}</ref>
=== Energy efficiency === {{Main|Efficient energy use}}
Moving away from fossil fuels will require changes not only in the way energy is supplied, but in the way it is used, and reducing the amount of energy required to deliver various goods or services is essential{{citation needed|date=November 2018}}. Opportunities for improvement on the demand side of the energy equation are as rich and diverse as those on the supply side, and often offer significant economic benefits.<ref>InterAcademy Council (2007). [http://www.interacademycouncil.net/Object.File/Master/12/053/Executive%20Summary.pdf ''Lighting the way: Toward a sustainable energy future''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071128074454/http://www.interacademycouncil.net/Object.File/Master/12/053/Executive%20Summary.pdf |date=28 November 2007 }}</ref>
A sustainable energy economy requires commitments to both renewables and efficiency. Renewable energy and [[efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] are said to be the "twin pillars" of [[sustainable energy]] policy. [[American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy|The American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy]] has explained that both resources must be developed in order to stabilize and reduce carbon dioxide emissions:<ref name=am>American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy (2007). [http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20090429195906/http://www.aceee.org/store/proddetail.cfm?CFID=785209&CFTOKEN=22090724&ItemID=432&CategoryID=7 ''The Twin Pillars of Sustainable Energy: Synergies between Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Technology and Policy''] Report E074.</ref> <blockquote> Efficiency is essential to slowing the energy demand growth so that rising clean energy supplies can make deep cuts in fossil fuel use. If energy use grows too fast, renewable energy development will chase a receding target. Likewise, unless clean energy supplies come online rapidly, slowing demand growth will only begin to reduce total emissions; reducing the carbon content of energy sources is also needed.<ref name=am /> </blockquote>
The IEA has stated that renewable energy and energy efficiency policies are complementary tools for the development of a sustainable energy future, and should be developed together instead of being developed in isolation.<ref>International Energy Agency (2007). [http://www.iea.org/Textbase/work/2007/bestpractice/Workshop_Proceedings.pdf ''Global Best Practice in Renewable Energy Policy Making'']</ref>
